title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
This game is one of the best in the genre. A great story that you for sure will remember and make you believe you're in some Godfather movie. No other developer ever got close to Hangar 13's depiction of "The Family Life"

However this remaster unfortunately is probably the sloppiest work I've ever seen. When even the classic version runs better, sounds better and looks better. Hear me out, here. This "remaster" mainly added higher resolution textures. But nothing else to it. Increasing the size of the game from 7GB to 40. For no good reason at all. The textures while they do look great, looks completely out of place to the rest of the world of Empire Bay and everyone in it. During a conversation you still see NPC's to your left that is completely untouched or re-textured.

Especially noticable on the landlady in Joe's building. You will find her character everywhere, as well as the "Red Fox" call-girl that shows up pretty much everywhere. Reused assets constantly. Even though this happened in the classic, it's a bit disappointing that no thought were gone into fixing things like this.

What makes the game even worse is all the bugs. It's been out for a while now and very little has been done to eliminate things that never even existed in the Classic version at release. Misaligned cameras, assets clipping (Such as wearing your hat around your throat instead of on your head) Glitching AI that seems more interested in the wall than actually apprehending you. Especially noticable during the robbery where the Irish interrupts you. When escaping from the police, they don't even exit the stairwell to the roof before you shimmy across the billboard. I had to kill them and reload twice, before I got the prompt to shimmy across. And I had to enter the stairwell and blow away the cops that seemed more interested in inspecting their shoes and the wall instead of attempting to chase us.

Another mission where the AI's aim is so good you won't even make it to the first intersection that is about 20 yards in front of you when you start the mission. I did make to the second a few times before I gave up. Restarted the whole mission just to try to get a faster car before exiting the compound after the first meeting with the Chinese.

Everything, even the game play is completely broken in comparison to the classic version of this game while looking old, still at least look homogenous. No textures stand out too much to make it look like it doesn't belong there. Which unfortunately they do a lot here.

There is nothing definite with this version of the game. It's the most disappointing remaster I have ever come across. Not even the PhysX effects work as they should, leading you to delete the folder for clothes for them to at least use the basic ones that Hangar 13 implemented to even work. Unfortunately meaning only YOUR clothes will have some kind of physics while everyone else will look like they came from the original game released 2002. How this ever passed to release is something I will never understand. They should have made a proper remake of it just like they did with the first one. And released it afterwards. I'm happy I got the game for free, courtesy of owning the original game on Steam. At least I didn't lose any money on this. Because it sure feels like a loss. Just buy the original and play through that instead.

Another glitch I forgot to mention is the sound. The volume of the conversations aren't on par with each other. One line will play super loud while another will force you to increase the volume to even hear them speak. A lot of other conversations doesn't play at all. Subtitles ON my friends.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Bought the definitive trilogy. I won't even bother playing 3 because it was bad enough on the initial release, I don't care what definitive has to offer there haha. Moving on.. Mafia II was the bang for the buck I was looking for. Everything was perfect. Story, physics, your advancement in the game and feelings of reward. Enough free-roaming to keep you entertained. Only qualm is after you beat it, there's no *continue in free roam* option so it's just "chapter select" from then on, which works fine.

Graphics, also great. I did find that the game performs outrageously (low fps) on High physx, with zero difference while using Medium physx -- specific to some areas, i.e. points within the distillery mission.. Using an overclocked 2070 super on my i9-9900kf @ all core 5.0ghz.. I do consider this likely is just another case of crysis-tessellation but either way, visual appearance doesn't change at Medium and I can maintain my steady 144fps now. All other settings @ high seem to be OK

To note as well, Mafia: Definitive Edition (the first installment) was very glitchy, wasn't super impressed. But between the two, I consider my purchase worthwhile. As also already said, I won't be bothering with 3, and I might say YMMV on that one, but I don't think it will xD

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia 2: DE. A game developed by Hanger 13 and D3T Studios and Published by 2K Games.

If you're familiar with my Mafia: DE review, you know basically what i'm gonna say here. The Mafia trilogy are up there amongst my favourite of this genre, The grit and violence means they are a cut above the rest, And debatable whether Mafia 2 or 3 reigns as the best of the series in my opinion. I would like to mention here, that i don't quite recall quite what  was available in the original rendition of Mafia 2, So i will be trying to review this as its own title entirely.

Story: 8/10
Having already played Mafia 2, and knowing the ins and outs of the story, the twists and turns in it still captivated me this time around. You play as Vito Scaletta an up and coming criminal in 1940's "Empire Bay" which is essentially just a soft rework of New York of the period. You are busted for some low end crimes and begin the game in service of the army. Upon leaving service you meet up with long time friend Joe Barbaro and your first steps toward becoming a "Made Man" begins. I rated this story so highly not because it isn't a cliche mafia story full of betrayal and intrigue.but because of how fleshed out Vito is as a character. His background, his interests and his personality are all almost readily apparent and begin to develop as the game progresses. I would also like to mention that this game pulls no punches. It's filled to the brim with racism, violence and sex. This adds to the realism of the era's grit and immerses you but its by no means for the faint of heart.

Gameplay: 8/10
+ Movement: A slight increase in mobility from the first game, Vito moves fairly smoothly around the world, his ability to vault short obstacles and that's position on the controller (I play 3PS games with a controller because it allows you to move slower in stealth) makes alot more sense and is far less clunky than it was in the first game. This doesn't mean its without flaws though, Vito still has a hard time navigating tight areas and often will "take cover" against completely irrelevant surfaces and get shot in the face because of it.

+ Gunplay: The gunplay here is hard to argue with, the guns feel effective and powerful and sound completely immersive, When you heart people belting out full mags of a tommy gun into the cover you're hiding behind and you hug it hard because you know peaking will clean your clock.

+ NPC/World Interactions: While the world isn't exactly ALIVE. Because the game takes place in Episodes across a 10 or so year gap, the world changes quite rapidly. But even so, each individual experience is full so to speak with people to talk to, and people living their lives, and you can really feel that as you run and drive Empire Bay's streets. My only qualm is that police seem completely disinterested with the NPC's breaking laws and only focus on you. It would add to the experience if police pulled people over occasionally.

+ Driving: While NOT as immersive as the completely remastered Mafia DE, Mafia 2 DE is still quite a solid driving experience, the cars react like you would imagine they would to the certain environmental effects, rain and snow. But also smashing the rear of you car, leaves quite a significant dent in that spot which was a nice touch.

+/- Fist Fighting: I couldn't decide if this was a positive or negative. Perhaps its both, perhaps its neither, But seeming it takes up a large portion of the game time, I have to mention it. It's great to see the mechanic where you get locked into fist fights with groups, shakes things up from the whole run and gun gameplay, But its not done particularly well here. Its pretty hard to monitor what your opponent is going to do and because Vito isn't particularly agile, he seems to get smacked in the face quite frequently.


- Difficulty: This game is easy. Far too easy even on the hardest difficulty, I don't recall it being so easy the first time i played it through but this time it was a breeze, i wish there was a realistic difficulty where gun shots actually took their effect on you, slowed you down, made your aim weaker etc. But unfortunately the overall difficulty was mild.

- Mission Diversity: One of the things that makes these kinds of games captivating is taking part in a lot of different experiences, The first game pulled this off amazingly. The 2nd..Not so much. There isn't a lot happening here, beyond driving from here to there and fight off waves of enemies until you reach your objective. A strong dynamic for sure, but it gets boring by the 10+ hour mark.

Visuals: 5/10
I was hoping for more, from the definitive edition, the touch ups weren't enough to warrant replaying the game. The game still suffers from what it always has, graphical glitches to make your character and the characters your talking to look completely broken or animations completely broken, breaking the total immersion as a whole. The remaster was almost completely irrelevant. The game is extremely graphically glitchy, in fact the first mission i played i jumped out of the cinematic car, and a woman was half way through the concrete of the footpath. Not a great experience. Surely without a doubt though on a mid to high end PC this game ran flawlessly high frames, Which i would expect no less because much of the world is still geometrical.

Audio: 7/10
Its hard to rate the audio bad here, apart from a few audio glitches that occurred frequently at the start of the game, completely loss of sound in 1 ear on my headphones or crackling as people talk, or completely cutting out entirely. But the soundtrack and audio here was expertly done back in the day, and were made to seem aged even then, It doesn't suffer in the slightest, if nothing else i feel as though it might have helped the immersion.

Overall: 8/10
Mafia 2 was a trophy winner of its time, perhaps the best Mafia game ever made (Up for debate with 3) but the Definitive Edition didn't bring much to the table, the game suffers from what it always suffered from, graphically and gameplay wise, But now suffers from its aged graphics and a new slew of audio concerns. I received this game as a freebie as many who owned the original did, But its really not any different from its original experience. Other than a very limited assortment of face touch ups to make it not seem as old as it is. A worth while experience for the sake of the trilogy but if you are after the same dedication here as the first games Remaster was, you're going to be sorely mistaken. For the price of $70 AUD for the DE trilogy though, i would warrant that price seemingly it included a full remaster, a rework and all the DLC's.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
My favorite Mafia game so far (have not finished the og M1 due to it being real clunky these days and because of M1 DE). Has it all imo that it needs to have to be an amazing mafia game. A good story, wtiting (though these two kind of fall appart in the final 3 chapters due to it feeling really rushed with a bit of an abrupt end which is kinda meh) and acting. Great soundtrack. Still some great graphics (for a 2010 game) and physx is always a plus in my book (and the default destructible environments are real nice too and better than any other mafia game by far). The open world is also the best in any mafia game with different types of stores all around the city and side jobs which makes this city feel way more alive than any other mafia game (especially 3...). I also prefer the gunplay and overall feel of the gameplay in this game to the others, even M1 DE in some aspects. My only gripe may be that there is a bit too much just driving around throughout the game for me. Even though it is a part of the series, it gets a bit old sometimes. But why do I not recommend it? Oh i tell you why.

Definitive edition my ass! All of the above is pretty much true for both versions, but there are things that I encounter in this one that I have never encountered in my numerous playthroughs of the classic version. Sure, some minor bugs still carry over (which may be acceptable to some, not me but they do not really get in the way), but there are a couple of GAME BREAKING bugs in this version. I have had to restart 3 chapters because the final mission "locks" up and wont let me progress and crashing a couple of times. I have also encountered numerous dialogue scenes in cars that are broken where every person in the car speaks at the same time making it impossible to understand what anyone is saying. Also the physx effects are downgraded and you need to go into the config files to even unlock some of the missing features. 

Beyond the audio and game glitches, there are a couple of visual bugs too. Some effects even seem like bugs but they are meant to be like that (Lights in the tunnels being blinding and not in a realistic or good way). Performance is also really odd. Sure, the physx looks amazing to this day and the graphics are nice, but 18 fps on a pretty powerful machine is not acceptable. The graphical upgrades are not close to being good enough to warrant the performance impact that it has.

So all in all. Mafia 2 is a great game imo, but Mafia 2 Definitive Edition is an overpriced and inferior product to Classic. If you want to play an amazing game, buy Mafia 2 Classic for cheaper. Definetly not a perfect game, but I still even to this day have alot of fun with the game. But stay away from this edition of it. A true disappointment to all fans of the series.

Mafia 2: 8.5/10
Mafia 2 DE 5/10

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II: Definitive Edition is an updated release, a HD remaster, of an already HD game that features enhanced models, textures, changes to lighting and the sound engine of the game. The game does look nicer at in motion. Some changes, like the greasy hair and the somewhat shinier eyes do look a bit strange, and I have noticed a few interesting artifacts with the Ambient Occlusion implementation, but generally, the game does look nicer. The nicer graphics don't necessarily explain the fact the download size of the game is nearly 5 times larger than the original, or the performance hit, but generally, the game does look nicer. As an owner of the original PC version of Mafia II on Steam, I received this version for free, while still keeping the old version in my library, which is a big plus (unlike Rockstar and the 'Complete' Edition of GTA IV that replaced the originals completely).

BUT, there are some issues with this re-release, starting with the first thing you see when you launch the game; the launcher is pointless. When I adjusted my settings so it would run in 1080p Borderless, when the game loaded up, it was rendering out at 480p full screen, but in a 1080p frame, so the game was in a tiny corner of my screen, and I had to navigate and change the options through the in-game options menu to get it running in the correct resolution. After getting the game to run 1080p, Borderless, Maximum settings (minus MSAA, which I ran at 4X and Vignette and Chromatic Aberration off because those effects are bad on a good day), I immediately saw they had re-done the pre-rendered cutscenes. Not just an upscaling, but they had re-done from scratch. The pre-rendered scenes look quite a bit better and might run at a higher framerate as well (which might explain the file size increase somewhat). Then the game crashed. After re-launching, Borderless Windowed Mode no longer worked, and when I tried running it through the options menu, the game threw up a load of messages about Nvidia Apex/PhysX, which is still in this version, but significantly gimped, and with no clear option to enable or disable the effects. Also, despite setting it to skip the launcher, every time I restarted, the launcher would load up first.

Once I got back onto the game, now in Fullscreen instead of Borderless, it loaded the in-game cutscene, and the audio was only going through my left ear on my headset. In-game cutscenes are mono on my setup, not pre-rendered, not actual gameplay, but the in-game scenes are. The shooty shooty bang bang part ran just fine, and audio was normal. The next in-game cutscene also ran in mono. Then the train station cutscene ran normally, then the in-game drive down the hill ran normally, and then the bar cutscene ran in mono. I was able to fix this by changing the in-game audio option to stereo and restarting the game.

Once I got to run around, I saw that the cloth physics were removed. This is disappointing, I have a Nvidia GPU so I was hoping these physics extensions would still work, considering that some PhysX particles are clearly still present, but they are not. Consequently, because some PhysX effects seem to be forced on, there may be a performance hit on AMD GPU's but I do not know for certain so take this statement with a grain of salt. Lacking the full PhysX effect experience has no impact on the actual gameplay, but it is a visual feature that is missing from the Definitive Edition that belies the idea this is the Definitive Edition for some players. Also, note that I did not run the game at an unlocked frame rate, so I can't comment on whether or not they fixed the bugs caused by running at over 100 FPS, such as the slow-motion glitch. Reading around suggests they have fixed them, but I cannot confirm that right now.

Graphically, as mentioned, the remaster is a mixed bag. Faces have benefited the most, but the eyes and hair look a little strange sometimes, appearing far shinier than they did originally. Artwork is generally of a higher resolution, pre-rendered cutscenes are completely rebuilt from scratch to use higher quality assets and run at a higher resolution and framerate. Lighting changes, such as sun effects and shadows have changed, with a stronger Ambient Occlusion process (with mixed results), higher quality shadows, including better actor self-shadowing, and a draw distance that seems to be further pushed back than it was before. The game generally looks better, although some of the artistic changes might throw you off.

Audio-wise, the soundtrack is apparently equal to what was in the base game in 2016, down 16 music tracks from the original release, some of which are on the better known side of soundtrack as well. It's far from what could be a definitive release, not quite on the same level as GTA IV, or the current state of the original Mafia if you buy it on Steam now, but that's little comfort. You are not getting the full original soundtrack experience. Apparently, some further tracks are also missing from the Joe's Adventures DLC pack, but I can't verify that myself, as I don't really want to play this version of Mafia II any further due to those technical issues. There is a mod to re-add the missing music, but you shouldn't have to mod a game to get the original intended experience. Audio mixing, by my ear, sounds a bit off in some places. Some sound effects have been replaced with higher quality assets that again I think work quite well but sound mixing seems off, even after I fixed the mono sound in some of the cutscenes, something still seemed off compared to what I was expecting to hear, as though the sound mixing in-game was wrong, with loud effects playing too quietly, something that does not occur in cutscenes, where instead it seems to lean a lot on my left speaker channel.

Overall, I can't recommend playing this version over the original. It does look nicer, but there are too many issues that make the Definitive Edition an inferior edition to the original version, which is still in your library and included in this versions purchase (or on GoG). Play the classic version instead. It doesn't look far worse (Mafia II still looks quite good) and suffers from far fewer bugs. Because this is a remastered compilation, it doesn't add anything, so you aren't missing out on any additional content unless you want to play the DLC mission packs (which aren't very good to be honest), and the original might not crash as often either.

Mafia II is a great game; the remaster is not the best way to play if you just want to play the game. The new version does not make a good game bad by any means (granted, I stopped playing before the end of hour two because I had enough of having to stop, drop out, tweak and come back to get the damn thing to work), but it is a sub-par re-release. Fortunately, unlike Rockstar, 2K aren't forcing you to use this version if you don't want to and unlike Rockstar's 'Complete Edition' mess, there are actual improvements that can be mentioned. The original release still works perfectly as long as you keep under 100 FPS on modern operating systems, it's also a HD game with a far smaller install size. There are too many drawbacks to truly call this game a definitive release. The classic release is included in this package, unlike GTA IV now, so I would recommend playing that version instead if you've never played Mafia II before.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
For someone who owned the original mafia 2 and finished it 5 or so years ago finding the definitive edition sure was a pleasant surprise. This was and still is my favourite game of all time just because of the story and simple yet remarkable mechanics the game has to offer. 

When I saw the screenshots of the definitive edition I was disappointed at first and wished for a bigger overhaul, but now after spending 10 hours completing the main story and driving around selling cars I am happier with this outcome than I would be with the kind of the graphical improvement Mafia 1 is getting. This style of a "remaster" was one of the greatest things that could happen to a 10 year old game that still looked incredible 5 years ago. Except of the few graphical improvements everything has stayed the same and thank God for that. 

The story has to be the biggest selling point of Mafia 2. It was such a blast replaying some of the most remarkable moments I have experienced in gaming story wise. The incredible and most loved characters like Joe and Vito have a huge impact on why the game is so brilliant story wise. Mostly all of the missions were unique and interesting but have to say the follow missions were a pain in the ass especially because of the speed limit we are forced to obey. I'm not going to spoil the ending but the cliff hanger it leaves on is so well done and thought out it had me shook and made me want to find out more about the story and find an answer to the question the game leaves us with. The overall amount of time it took me to finish the story was about 8 hours which makes more sense as the missions are unique. This is better than Mafia 3 where they extended the story by 10 hours just making the player do the same thing over and over again. I haven't completed all of the DLC content but I am planning to in the near future which will extend the playtime without making the game boring as shit. 

The difficulty level is somewhat challenging even on medium as you don't have much health and the enemies use automatic weapons which could kill you just in a few shots. The game wasn't frustrating because of it but made it more fun and a bit of a challenge which I really enjoyed. 

I experienced some minor bugs and glitches but most were rare and mostly were related to character's faces and clothes. I experienced an optimisation issue which was sudden frame drops which should not happen when using the hardware I use. Some were caused by automatic v-sync which was turned on for some reason but for some stutters I couldn't see why they were happening as they even happened when I tried playing the game on low settings. 

In conclusion, this is a must-play for anyone who has any interest in this genre not only in video games but also movies. If it wasn't for the DLC i wouldn't recommend buying the game for the full price but for all the DLC content and the main story paying £25 is a bargain. Personally, I can't wait what Mafia 1 is going to offer after finishing this game. Now I can truly say this is still my favourite game of all time.

review:
My rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece

Mafia series is without a doubt my personal favorite series of all time and I was very happy when the Definitive Edition Trilogy remaster was announced. Especially if you are into mobster content as I am. In comparison to other open world games, Mafia is different. The game is built around the missions you're doing and the focus is on the story, which is definitely a plus to me. The story is very captivating and relationships between the characters are something worth mentioning as this is a good example of a properly executed game. I was worried about the ending, but following the steps of Mafia 1, do not expect a cheesy one!

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review: Okay, so, i played a LOT of mafia 2, its my favourite game ever, i replayed it like 50 times, i know every nook and cranny of the game map, every little detail, all the characters, i can basically rehearse the story in my head. My friends can attest to this.The Remaster of mafia 2 is, odd, to say the least, some textures got updated, most notably the roads and the character textures, as well as some more minor elements and Clemente's slaughterhouse seems to have gotten a bit of a repaint too. Main Character models are way more detailed than the classic mafia 2 ones, and some voices of some minor characters have changed, like the soldier's in the intro mission.Markers, markers for enemies on hard mode have been removed, thats for gang members, cops are still visible on the minimap. Lighting has been changed as well, but nothing impressive by any stretch. There are also new gun sounds, which are very pleasant to hear. I honestly have no idea why this needed a remaster, you get some minor graphical upgrades and some postfx options and sounds, but besides that there is nothing to this remaster. Its mafia 2, but with a price hike. I got this because the classic version isn't sold anymore.They shouldve waited a couple of years, and remade this, just like theyre doing with the very first game in the franchise. I will not give this game a negative rating, as i cant give my favourite game a negative rating, as this game really means a lot to me, but i will say that this remaster was not needed, at the best it is unimpressive, and id rather have seen a full fledged rework rather than a not so impressive remaster.Classic mafia 2 still remains the best.

Install a widescreen patch for it and boom, 1080p game from 1998. Same for this modern game, right? WRONG!!

This game gets confused, and limits the game to the lowest resolution of the system. I can't go past 1280 x 1024, because this game sees I have a monitor with that resolution, and decides that is what my computer is capable of. Edit the settings file, you may ask? You know what plays fine in 1080p? Mafia II Classic. Save yourself 42GB and play Classic.

This game certainly is the Definitive Edition. Definitively bad.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II is a remastered edition of the classic game, including better framerates and better visual fidelity. The game tells the story of Vito Scaleta and his best friend Joe, with their rise through the mafia ranks; without spoiling too much, Mafia 1 & 2 have some of the best story-telling in previous generations, with the first game being fully remade later this year. 

The game takes place in Empire Bay, with a semi-structured open world modeled after New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. The game takes place over the time period of the 1940’s & 50’s, with great attention to detail within the world ranging from the architecture, cars and music. The game is told in Chapters with structured missions, controlling Vito in a third person perspective.

If you have not played Mafia II before it is well worth playing, some have been complaining about this edition only being a remaster, but it is still a fantastic game. This game's price point IS £24.99/$30-35. Depending on your taste for these types of games, it may be worth waiting for a sale; also, the game is free to you on steam if you own the classic version already.

Mafia II was one of the finest games of the last generation, I highly recommend picking it up at some point.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Probably a 5/10, but more of a No than a Yes. Such a let down after the absolute classic that was the first game. I liked the atmosphere, the interiors, the soundtrack and to a lesser extent the gunplay. But the game feels so cutback, so rushed, so unfinished. It starts out feeling like it has real promise, but I feel they must have run out of time or budget because by the end I was rolling my eyes and checking the clock.

Frequent game breaking bugs forcing restarts, baffling exclusions like no shooting from cars (when every other character in the game can), characters ranging from forgettable to irritating, predictable story, dull writing, loads of loose ends, no real sandbox, tedious speeding fine mechanic (yes, this was in the first game and no I didn't like it there either), risible AI (especially in cops who forget you exist when you walk around a corner, or your AI companions who I don't think got a kill all game), meaningless money and customisation options which are reset frequently throughout.

A lot of people seem to praise the story and writing of this one to the hilt, but frankly I'd prefer they just go back to ripping off Goodfellas if this is the best they can do on their own. I'd really be interested to see if anyone can list five personality traits of five characters from this game. I felt like I'd barely interacted with people my character was treating as a mortal enemy. I was utterly indifferent to people he treated like a best friend.

I don't really bother to write negative reviews, if I don't like a game I don't usually finish it, but after grinding along to the end of this grudgingly out of sunk cost fallacy, liking it less and less as I went on, I was just so annoyed I had to moan a bit.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Even though I received this game for free, and I enjoyed my time playing it, it’s still not worth recommending. I had read some reviews and seen that people were having trouble with the game running, crashing, and other graphical issues. I had only had one graphical problem and I thought it was funny so it didn’t bug me. That was until I got to the last quarter of the game and everything just decided to stop working. The game would crash, drop to about 20 frames, the world wouldn’t load, characters saying their dialog lines at both the same time and repeating them over and over again. 

It’s a real shame because I had a great time playing the game until the last parts. The story is something that I haven’t experienced in a game. It’s like playing a gangster movie and all the jobs they get are missions and first jobs are easy. As you play more the jobs start getting harder and things don’t always go as planned as usual. I loved how it was like playing through a movie and the soundtrack helps get you into the right atmosphere. It’s a big plus that it doesn’t share songs in Fallout. At least all the times I was listening to the radio I didn’t hear a single song I heard from another game that tries to use old vintage songs.

The gameplay is fun but there is a lot of driving. At first, the driving is great because it gives you time to get to know characters and there are a couple of funny conversations. By the 10th mission, you will be getting tired of driving every place you go. The missions and the tasks you have to do for people make you feel like a gangster. The game does a good job of telling you what it’s like to get into the Mafia and the lifestyle of those in it. The gun sections can be a little difficult which is good. I played on medium difficulty and there were plenty of times I died because I trying to spray and run through. Its that difficulty that’s just hard enough to make you stop and think of an approach but it won’t take you more than a couple tries if you die.

If the game was more functional I would give this game a thumbs up but sadly we live in a time where games we buy aren’t even completed on release. I never got around to playing the original/classic version but I’ve heard that if you can get your hands on it, its the better version. That is all.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II Definitive Edition Review

Release Date: 19 May 2020

*Note that I did not play for 2 hours as I was offline for most of the time, it was near 8 hours instead*

Pros:
The Mafia franchise has had its highs and lows and this, is at its peak, if we only consider Mafia II and not the definitive edition that is. The story is rich and although it is increasingly unrealistic to go guns blazing, that serves as a fun entry point for those who are new to the Mafia series. Maintaining its grittiness and your frustration at cops chasing you for speeding and so on. Yes, cops do matter in this game surprisingly. That aspect allows you to play in a more realistic manner aside from the shooting and explosions and that cops do give you a sense for needing to stay in the shadows and to blend in with 1940s and 1950s American society as an Italian immigrant. The story itself makes sense, the characters make sense, the dialogue makes sense and so rather than immersing you in a game such as Mafia II, it more so immerses you into a movie. Every cutscene and action from the original deals like an award winning film featured from the 70s or 80s and could be comparable to greats such as The Godfather and more modern takes such as The Irishman.

Cons:
The definite edition offers an extension pack to you for free. A ****load of bugs, glitches and optimization issues. Luckily, most optimization issues have been fixed except for the random crashes whilst bugs and glitches could range from Vito "getting up" by punching his feet through the bed and eyes pointed in a very unnatural direction during cutscenes. Textures and and coat clippings were also found annoying amongst the populace but I guess it was expected for since it was Hangar 13's job to remaster a timeless game. As they have done a poor job with Mafia III alone, they brought that inexperience into Mafia II purging of anything that is good in the game.

Verdict:
If this was a review about the classic Mafia II, this game would have gotten a higher score, but since it isn't, there isn't much to say before giving it a awfully weak,

6/10

as I still recommend it but you shouldn't bother.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
A classic, fantastic game at the time of release (original Classic version) with a good story, rich characters, comedic elements, a bunch of cars with their own characteristics, a beautiful city, and for the most part very enjoyable.
Reviewing this in 2020 as the DE version, it's surprisingly limited in terms of the AI of 'background' characters (just jumping out in front of your car, for instance), it doesn't feel all too 'open' really - the story is pretty much linear, the game is also relatively short (do not expect anything ANYWHERE NEAR GTAV) which I didn't recall it being so but back then it was probably fine, though there is still a good 12-20 hours worth in there.
It does also have a bit too much 'filler' in there when it comes to tedious tasks and should you fail at any point it is likely to throw you back further than seems right at times.
On hard difficulty, it's challenging but not overly so, though losing the police seems a bit too easy still.
Graphically, it looks good, but it does have some glitches - one terrible case of this is with Leo [spoiler]at the end of the game while you are riding in the car with him, his eyes are like a dog looking upwards[/spoiler] which is embarrassingly bad that it made it through ANY kinda of QA process.
The music, voice acting, and all that jazz is superb - it really gives it the right feels in all regards.
[spoiler]It also has one of THE great call-backs in gaming history, imo, when you get to see old Tommy Angelo once again, truly loved seeing that again[/spoiler]

I'd recommend this game still, for sure, but it has to be said - it has it's flaws, mostly just graphical glitches - but it's still as good a Mafia game as anything else out there, though in terms of content it's maybe around 5% of what you get with GTA V, as a comparison.

(Owned Classic version, received the DE 'upgrade' for free.)

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Over the years, Mafia II was always that milestone I knew I had to get it done with at some point, but seeing how I lacked the proper consols and capable PC growing up, It did not go as planned. All I had that related to the game was the same old graphics comparison video with it and GTA IV, however, now and after I played through the marvelous Mafia I, I finally get to taste from this forbidden apple, the game everyone praises to death, to the point where I probably never heard anything negative about it.

Well, the first frame hit, and sweet mother that was a huge step-up, seriously, I played the Definitive Edition that was released a month or two ago, and I did hear that the remaster wasn't that big aside from some texture enhancements and color calibration and oh boy dis it a looker. I don't play the latest Tripple A games so I'm not quite familiar with the state of the art graphics that hit the headlines, but I gotta say, it even holds up to GTA V in some areas and even surpasses it in a few details and gimmicks.

The story. I progress like your typical mafioso saga, even picking up on the first entry's notes, split into chapters with varying time skips that follows this trouble-maker and his childhood friend make it from street crooks to made-men. And the plot really makes you work for it. The levels are challenging especially on the hardest difficulty and even the medium one keeps you on your toes. The shootouts are unforgiving and the cops can get really brutal. I love the wanted system and how you have to be smart and cautions in order to stay low on record.

The driving system was definitely a step up from the first game, although, the simulation option did not add much, almost as if it was never there.

The characters are engaging, take the protagonist, Vito, I would always have Mafia I in higher regard in terms of the story and setting, but Vito takes the cake over Tommy as the main character. He's cool, classy and his development shows. He's like the anti average GTA protagonist where the character can do 180° between cutscenes and gameplay. Joe was the perfect side-kick, always there for his friends and true to his mafioso identity, brutal but also loyal. So good in fact that the last quote in the game moves you to tears having him as a center. And last but not least, Henry. He always had a faint but persistent presence in the story, not always there but somehow always involved, very likable, and interesting fella.

I wish the game had a Free Ride Mode like the first game because as soon as you finish the story, you're stuck loading previously finished chapters in case you want to do some free-roaming. Thankfully, there were 3 DLCs that unlocked the ability to free-roam as much as you want, moving their story from a per-chapter model to more of a GTA open-ended mission checkpoints scattered all over the map.

All in all, amazing game. Definitely, one to play over and over again. Especially the arcadey DLCs that go all the way leaderboarding on you and all, encouraging replayability and grind.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Why I don't recommend this game and by extension the original Mafia 2. I won't be writing a review of the original Mafia 2 since I would basically be writing most of the same things. However, i'm choosing to review this because in terms of purely cosmetic things it's for sure worse. First off I will give some credit where it's due, the devs of this game didn't ignore the crappy launch and fixed the gamebreaking and annoying bugs. As a downside to that though, that basically renders this game original Mafia 2 with free dlc and some bonus content if you own Mafia 3. So it really adds pretty nothing new. Now yesterday (the day before i'm typing this review.) I marathoned this game starting at the earlier mission I had started on and beat it from the 3rd act to the 15th over about 6 hours. By the time I had gotten to the end my only complaints were how annoying the cops were, the fact that there are several parts where you lose your hard earned weapons afterwards, and that you can't kill any of the bosses yourself during gameplay. However, my biggest complaint and the reason I decided to mark this review negative and also not recommend the original Mafia 2, is the ending. This a GTA clone don't get me wrong on that. I did enjoy the references to Goodfellas, Scarface, and the Shawshank Redemption. However, anyone that as played GTA knows that at the ending of the game when credits roll, you can hit continue and cause carnage and destruction like you never had before on the open world map, because you unlocked all the weapons and cool stuff. Now in this game after the credits roll and you are taken back to the main menu and hit continue story, I was expecting to be taken to the main map for some sandboxing, but instead I got started over at the ending mission. That was one of the biggest gaming disappointments in my entire life. 

pros 
maybe some free dlc and mafia 3 easter eggs 
old gangster and prison movie references 

cons 
nothing new 
horrible horrible ending 


Overall do not recommend but if you still decide to play this game, you're better off picking up Mafia 2 classic for cheaper. 1 out of 10 solely for the good references. This game could have done really well as a GTA old world Mafia game but it absolutely failed where it needed to shine and the references sadly while they are entertaining can't save the actual gameplay.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
MAFIA 2 is an all-time classic and one of my favorite games to date. I finished Mafia II (Classic) twice in the past on my old PC. And as devs very generously granted me a free copy of Definitive Edition, I couldn't wait to play it again on my new system and as of right now I'm on chapter 15, specifically going for "Ladies Man" achievement.  
To be very honest, this is a very well made reshade. Lighting, textures, reflections represent the technological advancement we saw since the release of the original. I don't have any negative remarks, except the game could be a bit more optimized in PhysX section and a few very weird bugs.  
Ultra preset PhysX can cause framedrops in very intense gunfight situations in open roads on entry level PCs (Ryzen 1200, 1050Ti, 8GB ram, 10Gb pagefile set on SSD in my case) and I've had a few hiccups while driving under the streetlights inside the tunnels.  
Bugs include texture glitches, character animations etc. The launcher in particular is awful, should NOT have included that, and I had to relocate my Documents folder just to be able to autosave, because the game glitched.

All in all, I'm satisfied with this. Nothing more can be said about story. Linear but deep story about friendship and loss. Voice acting is great, accents really shine on Italian characters. Driving mechanism, cars, music nicely represent 50's era. It's a 7/10 in my book. Good job nonetheless, Hangar 13!

P. S. Eagerly waiting for Mafia remake :P

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Let's be clear about what Mafia II Definitive Edition is: it's a very lazy graphical remaster with no other meaningful enhancements made to the original game from a decade ago. You can watch side-by-side comparison videos and see how little noticeable difference there is. Vito has blue eyes now and looks a little more tan? Maybe the textures on cars are a little sharper? Basically this looks like the original game with a reshade mod enabled. Apparently they've fixed some bugs which affected the original game on high refresh rate monitors (I was still a 60hz pleb back when I played the original so I can't say), but in exchange they've removed the PhysX elements for some reason? If you were hoping for, say, some of the additional content notoriously cut during the Mafia II's development to be restored here, fuhgeddaboutit.

Since I got Mafia II Definitive Edition for free for owning the "classic" version of the game, I guess I can't complain too much, but if I paid for this, I'd be upset.

Underwhelming graphical upgrades and cut content "might have beens" aside, Mafia II is still a game worth playing, and didn't get as much respect as it deserved because people expected it to be GTA with fedoras, which it just isn't. However, while it's an enjoyable experience, it's also quite a short one. If you're wanting to play the game for the first time you're looking at paying thirty bucks for 10-15 hours of gameplay, which is a bit dear. If the "classic" edition of the game was still readily available for PC at a lower price (like it was on Steam until the remaster was released...) I'd say just buy that. Buuut it isn't.

That being the case: If you haven't played the game before, get this, but get it on sale. If you've played it before, there is no reason to play the "Definitive Edition" apart from nostalgia, it plays and even looks (almost) exactly the same as the game you remember.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
This game has a lot of problems. First off, it is barely any different from the original release a decade ago. It went from looking like a game that was published in 2010 to one that was published in 2012. It's very clear they only re-released this game as a gimmick to advertise for the original Mafia remaster. This game does not come close to meeting the standards of a game released in 2020. The animations are very minimalistic, choppy, not fluid, and unpolished. There are several visual and audio glitches and bugs, none of them game breaking, but annoyance nevertheless. They did fix one game breaking bug from the original release in the second to last mission where you could not progress, which is good. 

All this being said, the game is still worth playing. The story is one of the best narratives from this genre, even if it may not hold up in places. I'm glad 2k made the decision to give everyone that owned the original versions of Mafia 2 and 3 the definitive editions for free. There would have been even more backlash otherwise. It was also a nice gesture to include the DLC expansions with the definitive edition, as I never would have played them otherwise. They shouldnt have released the definitive edition for this game however. They should have waited until Mafia 1 remastered was finished, and then gave Mafia 2 the same treatment. Yeah, it would have been resource heavy and they might have other projects they want to focus on, but it's a missed opportunity with a game that deserves a remaster.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
I received this game for free since I already owned Mafia II (Classic)
The graphics in this game truly have improved and I enjoy how realistic things like the streets and cars look in this remaster. However, I also have had the immersion breaking bugs such as:
- Vito glitching through his bed like a T-pose when waking up
- Audio during driving scenes repeating itself (almost like the same track is being played twice, with a slight delay)
- The eye lines of several characters (Leo, Henry) do not line up right when speaking during cutscenes, as if they were not animated
- When playing DLCs I have had scripted events get stuck which causes me to fail over and over again.

The definitive edition includes the classic Mafia II. I highly recommend you just play the classic, and you can even get a 'remastered' texture mod pack to spice up the graphics. 

Storywise, I have always loved the story of Mafia II and still enjoyed the replay, even with these grievances.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia 2 is an instant classic. It still holds up great, even for being 10 years old. But this "remaster" was such a let down. I don't know whats up 2K, but this is not pleasing the fans. For this definitive edition of Mafia II, they really haven't done much. Yes, they've updated the textures a little bit, but it is plagued with problems. A lot of textures are super buggy. A lot of the character's eyes in cut scenes don't follow the person they are talking to, and are just completely still, which really kills the scene in some cases. There is just so many bugs in this that I've lost count. It is absolutely annoying.
Hanger 13 didn't even try to incorporate anything new, like, let's say some of the cut content(Purchasable Hotels, Working subway system, and more). Its just "Oh, here's some 'improved' textures, for $30." 
While I did receive this for free since I own the original version of Mafia II, this just isn't very fair for people who haven't bought the game at all yet.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II is one of my favorite games of all time. And it didn't deserve the rough treatment this "Definitive" Edition gave it. For quite a good chunk of the game, everything seemed in order. Characters enhanced, some more visual effects, maybe improved sounds? It's all very... unnecessary. But not a problem, it doesn't ruin the integrity of the main game.

... Until I got in deeper and deeper into the story chapters. Then I noticed characters' faces messed up as if it was a Garry's Mod video, cutscenes with broken segments, Vito having his hat shoved down halfway into his head as the back of his head got messed up, Vito getting up from bed quite literally, with him standing up as his legs sticked through the mattress as he "woke up". AI companions never moving from one spot to help you out, but still talking during shootouts. Scripted events like tailing missions failing because the car I went after got stuck on his own, and I was keeping my distance. Characters speaking over themselves, and repeating themselves, on the SAME conversation (even in the final encounter)... the list just goes on and on.

Issues, that I've never seen in over 10 years of playing Mafia II across different machines and consoles, happen all the time, specially crashing for no reason. Mafia II doesn't need Vito's hair going fullbright white during a cutscene with emotional impact - it just pulls you out from the experience completely. D3T, the studio responsible for this, did a very subpar job on this remaster, and it is a shame.

Don't let the title fool you, the Definitive Edition lies in the Classic Mafia II version. At least the best way to play is bundled with this mess of a "remaster", but with a way too step price tag compared to before, for a half-assed "upgrade". It runs better, looks just as good (even better in some aspects) and doesn't have these annoying issues.

Mafia II is definitely worth playing, but make sure you don't rob yourself out of an enjoyable ride with these technical issues. Play the Classic version instead.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
[b][u]So I'll be fairly brief with this review to not waste your time.[/u][/b]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

[list]
[*]Game looks better (subjective). It isn't perfect though; It's a remaster, not a remake.
[*]Some bugs have been fixed - Infinite loading etc I no longer experienced.
[*]You get a few clothing items both new and old depending on the edition/pack you bought.
[*]Apart from that. I honestly can't think of anything else for now.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

[list]
[*]A considerable amount of this remaster is unpolished. Down below isn't even a full list.
[*]Unrefined/polished performance: Game lags on a 2080 TI especially involving physics.
[*]Heads warping with the joints etc contorting.
[*]Player hats clipping through the characters head to mouth level leaving the top of the head jagged and crushed down.
[*]Audio Problems such as the audio playing in multiple layers with a 1 second or so delay.
[*]AI is heavily unrefined. If you play on hard, get ready for them to shoot you before even looking your way or even 
[*]when they are staggered by gunfire. 
[*]Some of the textures are clearly inferior to the original (again subjective). 
[/list]

Plenty more cons can be added. Not to sound rude, but I doubt they even had QA testers on it. Too many issues so I can't recommend it.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
This review pertains ONLY to this "definitive edition" of the game. 
Please see my review of the original Mafia II (2010 Release) here -> https://steamcommunity.com/id/JasperCarmack/recommended/50130?snr=1_5_9__402

+ Character skins now have subsurface scattering
+ A few upscaled textures here and there

- Does not run well
- Crashes consistently when the player has entered/left a garage multiple times (usually when 'building up' cars and doing things between missions, so you will lose a lot of progress very fast)
- Buggy. Some character heads did not show up sometimes, so I would be seeing eyeballs floating in the air in front of me. Animated sprites and VFX would flicker violently and jump around their origins
- High res Textures suffer from "HD Texture syndrome", with loss of original style choices and appearance. This is most definitely a minor nuance and not a major gripe, but it does fight against Mafia IIs original soft, stylised textures that complimented its appearance from when it originally released.

Also legit, why does Joe Barbaro have completely different coloured eyes now? He looks like a different man.

I cannot recommend this new version as it has many bugs, runs poorly, and texture updates don't realy make enough difference to justify it.

I highly recommend you play the original Mafia II release from 2010.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Shorter than I remember but still a great game.

I've just completed Mafia 2 Definitive Edition in around 11 hours, which makes it a relatively short game, although I didn't do anything other than plough through the story missions; not that there's a great deal else to do, besides selling cars, robbing the odd shop or looking for collectables. Mafia 2 was criticised at the time for having an open world without much to do in it but I see it as simply the setting for a good story. While part of me wishes that the experience was longer, and that I could have played out a couple of the cut-scenes, rather than simply watching a montage of my criminal activities, I think this would have impacted on the flow of the game and the story.

At first glance the graphics seem the same as I remember but take off those rose-tinted glasses and you realise that they have actually been nicely updated. Cars look the part and handle well and everything fits the period, providing a great atmosphere; the soundtrack too is also really good. Shooting and brawling obviously play a large part in the game, with gunplay being of the "press button to hide behind cover, hold aim to pop out" variety; again, it works well and I have no complaints here.

There has been a lot of talk of this being a poor remaster, so let me just say this:
if you have the original already on Steam, then you have this in your library right now, for free, which is how I got it, and it is definitely worth another play through.
if you have the original on another platform, is it worth buying this? Probably not, not for the current price. It's the same game (albeit with all of the DLC included) with some nicer textures and the occasional sound glitch or "eyes stuck looking to one side in cut-scenes" glitch thrown in for good measure.
if you don't have the original is it worth getting this? I would say so. Maybe it's showing it's age in some areas but hey, forget about it. Now get outta here!

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
I honestly don´t get, why this remaster exists. Mafia II (Classic), how it´s called now, was still fine. At least, in my opinion.
Okay, they´ve redone many textures, for streets, sidewalks, clothes and the faces look better, too.

What they didn´t do is fix some of the mayor bugs. 

-You can still fail in Chapter 9 when you tailgate Luca and he crashes into another car, while trying to get on the highway.
-There is an annoying flickering goin on with the new smoke effects, that wasn´t present in the original. Also some of the trash, lying on the ground, has this flickering too and some of it has a unnatural yellow colouring. You can see this especially in the first few chapters, because of the snow, but it´s present troughout the whole game.
-The clothes physics semms to be much worse than in the original. On several occasions Vitos forehead just clipped through his hat, or his leather jacket trying to escape his body.
-There are way to many pop-ups. If you drive fast enough you can try to outrun the grass and flowers popping up.
-For some reason all charakters seem to have puppy eyes. Most noticably when they´re in dark envoirements and their eyes seem to glow.
-Also they claim that you get all the DLC´s with it. Thats a lie. At the time of this review, several DLC´s are missing. For example the War Hero Pack, the Vegas Pack and the Made Man Pack. Because of this some cars are also missing, like the Jefferson Futura, the Roller GL300 or the Cossack. You can however play Joe´s adventures and Jimmys vendetta.
-The Fight against Derek is still way too hard. You sit there in his Warehouse, while you get shot at from all sides an he is on the catwalk throwing molotov´s that will hit you TROUGH cover. And there is still no checkpoint after entering the warehouse. So you start on the opposite site of the harbour again and have to kill ~15 poeple until you run into the warehous and get killed again by molotov´s.

I have to mention, they´ve at least fixed the endless slowmo bug from the original, when you steal your first car. Too bad the couldn´t do that in the original.

Sadly, I can not reccommend this. True, I got it for free, since I own Mafia II Classic, but future players HAVE to buy this version, since the OG is pulled from the store.
It just feels rushed and unfinished. They were probably mid-reworking the game, when some manager, or something, walked in the office and told everyone they have to release the game soon, because of the Mafia 1 anniversary.

Edit: Okay, when I wrote this Review I had just finished Chapter 12. Now I´m at the end of Chapter 14 and can´t progress. My Mission is to pay bruno back. 55.000$. I have 55.298$ in my Inventory, but when I got to pay him back, I can´t interact with the door. Even restarting fom a Checkpoint doesn´t fix this.
My initial opinion was not too great, but this is the final straw. I won´t play this Chapter again, It´s my least favourite from the whole game. So, my playthrough ends here.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
[h1]Overall, Mafia II: Definitive Edition tells a story that is gripping and while it may not be largely unique in the span of Mafia lore, it’s one of the best available in video game form. I genuinely cared about Vito and the terrifying criminals that surrounded him. I grew to love their antics and laugh at their quirks, and feel sorry for the situations that they found themselves in. I think it’s a little unfair to class Mafia 2 as an open-world game, because the city does nothing but offer the setting for the story to go from point a to point b. 

If you’re looking for a city that is brimming with side quests and random activities, you won’t find them here. What you will find is a bittersweet, interesting period piece that looks at time that is not often explored in video games, and it’s a pretty damn memorable one at that.[/h1]

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
I'm really getting tired of this unfinished re-released mess of a game that claims to be "Definitive Edition" 

Update changes can be found the the end of review.

Disclaimer: Just because i have received it for free since i own the classic copy, it dosn't mean that i should tolerate the progressively lower quality end product, ESPECIALLY since it was better before. So i will try to inform the new buyers to what they are signing in for.

The graphical uplift is barely noticeable to classical version. Sure there are some changes like; super shinny surfaces, better makeup for our ageing characters, altered weapon sounds and God like car lights that can blind the blind person. Oh yeah and there is two new cars;
One ported over from Mafia 3 (with terrible damage model) and Mafia's 1 taxi Falconer only available during winter time? And that is it. Can't think of anything else atm.

The game is still missing 2 vehicles from "Made Man Pack" weird considering This Is "Definitive Edition" Now on to RNG Bugs: Every time you start the game you have a random chance to get rare, common or Legendary bug. ps. Epic bug just crushes your game to your desktop, at anytime of ur playtime...
Sometimes unloaded textures, sometimes unloaded Text. Sometimes no sound or smt. no minimap. Ohh and don't get me started on tailing missions, because you have a really good chance to repeat the whole BORING and SLOW section, just because the opponent is a total derp at driving and gets stucke on other cars, thus game decides to call it a day (failing mission) since you can't go up to him and help him out.. obviously.

Get use to it, this trend is becoming the new norm.  "oh but i got it for free, ehh its oke"
Good attitude..  xD Mafia 1 Remake goes live in about 2 months xD "its oke" and yes i know 
its not Hangar 15 who worked on this rrrresalle of mafia 2, they worked on Mafia 3 xD

I will keep review updated if something changes in upcoming weeks or a month. 
But im not willing to download 44GB again just because they woke up and decide to release patch months later.

Warning! Spoilers Ahead!.. sort of, its to help you save time.
Ps.[spoiler] Before you start the mission on chapter 12 "Sea Gift" round up 25.000 shmackles,
( preferably Deric's ;) place ;) You will thank me later.[/spoiler]

This re-release should be called "Definite Joke Edition" of once glorious game The Mafia 2.

Review note changes 01/06/20
Remove unnecessary spaces. I'd like to say that there is still a problem with earning some basic achievements which otherwise you would normally unlock easily.

Review note changes 18/06/20
+ Enforcer achievement can be now unlocked, and main campaign stats are now correct. 
Fun fact. Direct @k support website isn't helpful at all. good luck reporting bugs.
- Jimmy's Vendetta stats are still broken, preventing (me?) from obtaining other achievements like; Massacre, Sharpshooter, Firebug and Armament King. (Yes i did verify steam files).
- Still no "Made Man" pack cars available. (yes Iam linked to 2K)
- Weird fps drop that have not been present before. (Jimmy's vendetta) As of now.

Final Review note 26/06/20
This game will be uninstalled after I have finally reached 100% complition. 
Summery:
+ Nostalgia 
- I fell like this rerelase didn't deliver much of an experience like classic version did and some of us had a problems running it at 60FPS (it was all over the place). Some didnt have the problems but had same bugs scattered throughout the game despite their glamourus PC machines.
- Corrupted save games. (but i've managed to fix that, i will explain below)
So for same reason, good or bad. This game had my old (classical) auto-saves already present when I first installed the game. Most of which where negative sums that are closer to 
UK national Debt (of about -2.3 trillion)[-4.8Tril to be exact if counted all liabilities because of some F*#ki@! lockdown decision!! of a thing that might be just a flu! And Kill Bill is talking about 2nd wave!] alright ok ok...
So i fixed that.. you know how? xD 
I have copied and pasted my old save games from Classical superior version to DAssE save folder. AND... [i]it worked[/i] I was able to finish the rest of the missing achievements and my game run lot smoother without bad FPS drops [i]Magic[/i]

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
First of all, i got the game for free because i already had Mafia II.

I can understand all the other comments saying its a bad remake because of the amount of bugs occuring now ingame wich aren't present in the old game, but i'm positive the Dev's will fix them

Positive Things / What i like about the remake:
- Better lightning, reflections, volumetrics
- Street lamps have a really great lightning it looks very nice too see the city at night
- Shadows are more saturated and softer
- Way more detailed charakter skins
- Faces are more detailed, you can even see every freckle, scratch
- Beards better visible
- Hair looks now more like the gelled hair young folks had in the 40's
- The environment feels more reflected on the vehicles
- Objects that were actually round, but were rather angular due to the technology at that time, are now round
- More options to adjust the graphics and behavior of the game
- A "Launcher" gives you the chance to adjust the settings before you start the game and can also be turned off in the settings
- Cutscene movies are remade to fit the 1080p optic
- Film grain was removed in many occasions (never understand why it's a thing in games, same as motion blur)
- New arrangment of the Main menu
- Story is still the same (yeah i think this is a valid good point because many remakes do changes on it's stories)
- Xbox Controller work better now
- Even the remake can run easily with 60+FPS on most machines on highest settings

Negative things /What i don't like:
- Main menu now show an Ad for the "Definitiv Edition Collection"
- Why should i create an 2k account? And why the game needs to remind me about this everytime?
*Answer* You will get 2 new Cloth pieces ingame wich are both ugly in my opinion.
- Ingame cutscenes sometimes have problems with buggy characters, sometimes the eyes don't move, don't blink or just look somewhere else
- Smoke, Steam flickers sometimes and are a little "too much" and are not constant
- Some lights especially in the tunnels are way too bright and dazzling
- PhysX. Do i need to say more? Well, it "work" but only after you delete the "Cloth" folder in the game folder
- PhysX again - after fixing it, it will work, but your clothes start to wobble some time after your character stops moving 
and some other world objects will also begin to wobble too as soon as they move
- PhysX once again? Well not exactly but its still PhysX fault: DLC Clothes (Greasers, etc.) will not show up in your wardrobe if you don't delete the "Cloth" folder
- If you kill a NPC near objects like chairs, it will most likely happen that the object will spin away
- If you stealth-kill a NPC like a cop sitting on a chair, the NPC will stand up regulary because he see you, but then act like getting strangled and get unconcious without alerting anyone else
- Combat System is untouched and ducking is still a little clunky
- Movement with Controller is sometimes a bit loose
- They really could have reworked the tuning system, you can only make your car better, but you can't downgrade your car if you don't like the highest tuning because the engine goes through the hood which looks ugly on some cars
- Some objects still have their original graphics wich look out of place
- sometimes the characters glitch a little in cutscenes

There are sure many more things to mention but i think those are the most notable. 

Summary
- Do i enjoy the game? Yes of course
- Do i bitch about some bugs? No, because they are minor, yes i think they shouldn't exists in the game but well, here we are
- Do i recommend the game? Yes and No
-- If you loved the original and want to see the game polished in 1080p then yes, buy it or if you're lucky, you already have it for free anyway. 
--No, because some of the bugs can breake the immersion and fun for many people especially since the gaming community became very bitchy about anything what isn't 100% perfect (nothing can be)

All in all, in my mind, the bugs and everything negative i mentioned is somewhat minor and can be easily ignored, because Mafia II Definitive Edition is still a good game and a worthy successor of the original game and i really have fun playing it

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
This one is really hard to dislike just because I enjoyed the original so much. After ten years you'd think before they put this out they would have taken the time to fix some of the issues that it had even when it launched. Unfortunately not only are a lot of those old issues still there, but there are a pile of new bugs that make the game borderline unplayable. That being said I still played it all the way through and got over 50% of the achievements so I can really talk about this game. I played the original several times over the years, originally on console then eventually moved up to playing it on PC. Sometimes I'd play for just an hour driving around enjoying the atmosphere, others would be full playthroughs just to do it again. I'll state I played this version before and after the 1GB update they put out. So let me start with the pros and then I'll move to the cons. I also have a perfectly acceptable PC that shouldn't be a cause of any of these issues.

Pros-
Beautiful atmosphere now in higher definition.

Great radio soundtrack, though a few more songs would have been nice.

Fantastic car catalog with so many lovely renditions of cars of the era, slightly modified to not be direct copies they'd have to pay to use of course.

Ambient sounds were normally well done, always nice standing out by the road hearing the grinding of a non-synchronized manual transmission on a passing truck.

Story has always been good, not perfect but good.

Police AI when it wanted to actually work was always a nice touch, might be annoying to some but I love the thought of speeding tickets and bribes.

Little details like fuel consumption, losing hub caps, car wash, the price of fuel going up through the story. so few games really do it and it's just another one of those things that you can mostly ignore, but is just a nice touch.

Now on to the cons-
Buggy Glitchy mess. Constant never ending graphical issues, freezes constantly I wouldn't even call them micro-stutters because they could last for up to 5 seconds and could be as often as every 15 seconds or could be several minutes between but through the entire 16 hours I played they were always there. Get in a car? Stutter. look too fast? Stutter. Change the radio station? Stutter. Turn the PC around too fast? Stutter. You get the gist. 

Audio bugs galore. The radio stations were constantly having issues where the last few words of a radio report, or the last part of a song would hiccup and loop several times before it'd finish and go to the next. Talking? Sometimes it'd be an absolute pain because everyone would be stuck talking over each other 2-3 times so you can't make sense out of anything they are saying.

Vehicle AI was a huge issue, sometimes they were fine, and other times they were so unpredictable it's as bad as actually driving in Manhattan. Usually I'd not mention it because real drivers are absolutely nuts, but being on the highway and all the sudden a car up ahead is just parked on the expressway is ridiculous.

Pop in was awful, having cars just suddenly appear on their side or roof in front of you while driving was just ridiculous. I assume it could also be related to why the game is constantly stuttering as it tries to put everything together, but I honestly couldn't say.

Camera one of the biggest issues in this game is the awful camera, it was awful in 2010 and it's even worse now. It's a 3rd person view that's like being on a little ball turret a foot behind the PC, never looking exactly where he looks, but just in his general direction. Getting shot when you're peeking around cover because he would technically be able to see them, but your stupid camera can't is just bad camera design. RE4 had third person camera down in 2005, the GTA games got the hang of it more or less by San Andreas in 2004. There was no reason this 'Definitive Edition' couldn't have taken some time to fix the camera.

T-posing, clipping through the ground and other posing issues were also a constant issue and while not as much of an issue were still something that's probably not supposed to happen.

Shooting similar to the camera is something that really could have been improved in this edition, it's not the worst but the few times I died in the game were because the PC did something weird when I tried to aim to fire.

DLC not all there. Where's my Jeep and uniform? 

Those are all things to consider when you want to buy this game. They might fix it, it'd be nice if they did and if I see things are fixed I'll edit this review, it'd be nice if at some point I could recommend it but right now I just can't. I would have rather paid to get a Definitive Edition that fixed everything than just got my version upgraded when it came out. I really hope they don't screw up the Mafia original remaster because I played that game a ton too when it first came out. For now I'll keep this one installed but I probably won't be touching it for a good while.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia 2 is a solid game. The world is really barren (unless you like going around looking for porn or pictures of the developers), the writing is usually on the average side of things and the shooting and mission variety is kinda lacking. However the atmosphere and attention to detail easily carry the expirience throughout. In my opinion its worth a buy. On GOG.

 I see a lot of people reviewing it here saying that it only needs bugs to be removed, and THEN its worth a buy. While bugs are existent on this version (I expirienced a near-gamebreaking one near the end of the game that carried over from the original version), even if they are fixed in their entirety: this version raises the price, file size and system requirements so much, that its inherently inferior to the GOG version, because that one has the same content, is only 10GB and is currently less than 3 bucks. I recommend you buy that version and mod it to hell if you wanna make it look like this one. I bought this game back when it was the original and decided to play it once every owner of the original got this upgrade for free, so these issues didn't matter that much to me. But if you buy this now, the issues with this version will probably sour the time you spend with this game. Either wait for a deep deep sale or buy it on GOG.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Just finished the main game and IMO this re-release is great. I got this as I own the original release of Mafia II, and unbelievably, all the DLC came with it free as well, which I never owned before, so I'll be enjoying them soon.

Sure, its got some strange bugs, glitchy facial expressions and some of the achievements don't work (note how I've completed the game but somehow didn't get the achievements for completing certain chapters) but overall the presentation is very good. A lot of hate for the new lighting system, but I personally think Empire Bay at night looks much, much better.

Gunplay is the same, simple, straightforward and satisfying. Driving is fun and varied, and incredibly unforgiving.

Mafia II is short, but the attention to detail throughout the game is insane - from hubcaps rolling off your car when driving erratically, your car getting dirtier the more you drive in the snow, to the way the citizens of the city start the game not knowing who you are, to them knowing exactly who you are. Memorable levels, memorable chapters.

Still one of all time favourite game endings.
