title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II Definitive Edition Review

A Second Chance to experience this truly immersive 1950's Mafia open world action-adventure game!

Story:
9/10
You play as Vito Scaletta, a wannabe gangster and aid and get aid from and to your best friend Joe Barbaro who has been 
there for you for your whole life. You will experience so much together. So much indeed. The city is Empire Bay. Real life New York. So many opportunities, the American dream as they say. Will you accomplish that dream and so many other dreams that Vito has? How will Vito's story end?

Graphics:
7/10
Not that much improvement overall. Some of the textures were upgraded. Better lighting and facial structures of the main and sub-characters. Mostly, it's the same look from the Classic version. But of course there are bugs, glitches and lower fps and game performance with this game. 30 fps near many areas, even on strong rigs. The developers might fix these issues sometime in the future.

Gameplay:
8/10
The driving mechanics are so realistic! You won't find the GTA driving style here. The driving style here is a more brutal and realistic one, I would say. You get penalties from driving fast or not driving carefully from the cops. The shooting gameplay is rather simple. The weapons are rather impressive. I Like their design and sounds. As I stated above, the gameplay is open word so you can kinda explore and collect collectibles, only this can you do though. The game has achievements also, always a plus in my book, just like the classic version. Sadly, no more stuff beyond the main story missions and collectibles were added.

Soundtrack:
6/10
I wouldn't say that I am intrigued or surprised by the soundtrack, only the main theme puts me on chills. Some scenes have a powerful track out on them while others don't. Kinda a miss or hit or done by purpose.

DLC(3 in total)
5/10
Filler in my opinion. With the DE you get all of the DLC with the main game of course, so no losing here, you can play them or not, if you are an achievements hunter like myself you need to complete these and miscellaneous achievements that you can only obtain by playing the DLC's. All the DLC's have a timer on every mini-mission and you have a limited time given in order to complete the missions and do some extra work for the achievements (e.g Drifting daddy 'o', millionaire etc). The best one is Joe's s Adventures which covers the time gap on what joe did after a crucial point in Vito's life.
In Jimmy's Vendetta, well you guessed it: Jimmy's Vendetta!
And The Betrayal of Jimmy: Betrayal. In addition to these, you get various car and outfit themed DLC's and exclusive outfits from past mafia games to the most recent ones. (E.g. The Mafia III protagonist can wear Mafia II's protagonist's clothes and drive his car and so on)

In Conlusion:
Overall game score: 9/10
This is a nice addition to your Steam Library in general especially if you are a Mafia fan, have already completed the Classic Mafia 2 game, the story, the achievements etc or even a newcomer who wants to try a Mafia game and also get all the dlc included in the price and not independently. Then this game is for you. 100 %

Thank you hangar 13 for giving us another chance at completing the game again from the start, obtaining all the achievements, enjoying the game with a fresh look and of course giving it for free to the Mafia 2 Classic owners like myself!

P.S:
*The achievement "Enforcer" is bugged. Doesn't unlock even if you surpass the 50 enemy kills. The developers are currently working on a fix.
*I got the DE for free because I had already had the Classic Mafia II game. You will get the Classic Mafia 2 game for free if you buy the Mafia 2 DE. And vice verca.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Let me start off by saying that I recommend this game to those that have never played Mafia 2 before, or if you had played it on another platform and don't own the original on pc. The story is simply amazing and is a must play for people who have yet to experience it. 

It is easy to see why this "Definitive Edition" is getting the amount of hate that it is. If you don't own the classic version, then you are paying $30 to get both versions, with this version barely being an upgrade. There are some graphical improvements, but that is about it. The game still has a ton of bugs, and even more than the original. For instance, the newspaper salesman no longer has any audio and silently waves the papers about. The eyes still move in the cut scenes, to a degree. There are times where people look cross eyed during scenes. Even with the "improvements" graphically, the game still looks dated. The character models throughout the game are so re-used that it is slightly jarring at times, which I'm sure it has always been this way, but nostalgia forbids me from remembering it. Some of the cut scenes in the game don't seem to have been updated at all and look entirely the same as they did when the game was first released. 

With all of that being said, I think that all of the above can be overlooked and there can be a lot of enjoyment pulled from the game. This was the first time I have played since it was first released, and I enjoyed it just as much as I did 10 years ago. I can't state enough how amazing the story for this game is. If money is tight, I would say wait for a sale. If you have the dough to spend, go ahead and pick the game up.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Breaks my heart to put "not recommended" on a Mafia game, but here I am doing exactly that.

The first Mafia was my #1 favorite game for a long time, so I was really excited to play Mafia 2. But this games seems to fall short about everywhere. The environment is done decently, but it's not really as expansive as the first game, and that one is OLD. There's a story, but it failed to make me feel any real connection. The missions themselves are rarely interesting, and the way the story is set up, you do a whole lot of "drive to that place", that might actually be the bulk of my playtime. The only real interaction I had with the city was driving across it. The stuff they put in the city had no real significance to the campaign.

So, if you're like me and on a mission to go through all games in the series, Mafia 2 is kinda sorta OK, I guess it's worth a play-through. But for a game on it's own, eh. You time, storage, and bandwidth might be better dedicated elsewhere.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Loyalty, Respect, Betrayal 

This game is true gem in the Criminal underworld of games. It really immerses you into the experience of working for a mafia family. 

Remaster: 
I played this game 10 years ago on console when it first came out and loved it then just as much as i enjoyed this time around. The remaster improves the games graphics and could hold up to modern games of today with a few tweaks and patches. The cars, Charcter faces, and enviromental assets is what i noticed the biggest changes in as everything has had a fresh polish look to it colours are more immersive and brighter and more ambient. The way rain falls onto your car all the little details look way more realstic now than what they did. This game suffers the most from performance thoe as its not very well optimised for pc as there is constant frame drops and Ai issues but with a few tweaks this game will be a masterpiece. 

Police AI: 
One point I really want to talk about is how smart the Police AI were for the time. If you commit a crime you need to change your clothes otherwise police around the city will recongise you. Same if youre driving a the same car they can track your liscense plate if you hang around to long. All these little things even having to refuel your car for the time was different to everything else out there on the market. 

Story: 

10/10 amazing gripping story 

Gameplay: 

9/10 just needs a few more tweaks for performance 

Replayabilty: 

6/10 needs side missions 

Overall; 

9/10 Amazing game defientley worth your time.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia 2 has a special place in my heart. It's easily one of the best Mafia style games out there. To the writing, the characters, mature content, and the story. I love it. I bought this remaster because I wanted to jump back in and playthrough again with all the updates. I'm in chapter 9 and I feel like I have played enough to make an opinion on this remaster. Having played through the original release already. It's still the same great story (so far) with better textures and graphics. All the little glitches and bugs that you hear in other reviews are true, examples (blinking fog, graphic glitches, and eye tracking). You can fix some of the blinking on objects and fog by capping your frame rate to 60fps in the games settings. Which is a bummer for someone with a powerful PC. And performance is quite dog turds to be honest compared to the original. Even with a 2080ti and everything on Optimal settings. Physx is bugged and doesn't work for cloth. You shouldn't have to modify a file to fix that. I want to recommend this game, and it does some things right. But in the current state I can't. I really hope whoever is responsible for the patches see the reviews and fix these issues because it's a classic and deserves it. It'd be hard not to feel a little worried about the Mafia Remake. Please optimize it and put all the same effort and love in the finished product, as these fans have for the series.

Edit: I will update this review and give a recommended rating when the bugs are fixed.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia 2 was an awesome game that lots of people nowadays look back to quite fondly due to its narrative capabilities, gripping gameplay and great soundtrack. However, its visuals did not age so well, so here we have Definitive Edition aiming to polish and improve all visual aspects. Does it do it well? I would say its a great improvement and the best way to play this gorgeous game in 2020. It does, however, has its flaws - poorly optimized areas, visual bugs and glitches plus lots of the DLC characters textures have not been touched at all. Even through all of these mistakes I would not call it a sloppy remaster as all of the above mentioned can be fixed with patches and I hope that that is exactly what they will do. Overall recommended as if you are buying it for the first time, you will get classic Mafia 2 with all of its DLCs free of charge and same goes for if you already own the classic 2.

Pros:
+ Gorgeously polished already great looking game
+ Most of the areas dont really hit performance too much
+ Story still holds up today as one of the greatest Goodfellas-like style of storytelling
+ Gameplay is a bit on the arcady side with shooting, but drive still feels really good
+ Well crafted characters

Cons:

- Graphical glitches that are very apparent especially with newly added clothing such as Tommy Angelo´s suit and Clay´s jacket - character model is protruding through the clothes and the hat of the suit was sometimes stuck in the middle of Vito´s face during cutscenes
- Some places are poorly optimized for no apparent reason - there is nothing going on, no shooting or particle efects, it was even in the middle of the night but the game decided 15fps sounds like a treat
- DLCs still s*ck and that is cemented by the fact that creators of this remaster did not so much as a touch textures of side characters of the DLCs
- we have still got those annoying 30fps cutscenes but I guess there is nothing that can be done about those since they are pre-made

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Must've been around 10 years since I've played and finished the original Mafia II. I did really enjoy the game back then so when this remastered version came out I thought it would be a good time to endulge myself into the Mafia again. 

I did not play the original Mafia II first to see if this remastered version is a big improvement or not but from what I've seen the game holds up very nice even after 10 years. Empire Bay (a mix of Chicago, New York and San Francisco) still has an amazing atmosphere of that era and great to drive around in. 

That said, this is not a GTA clone. Yes, Mafia II is an open world game but there is not that much filler content like in GTA. Mafia II pretty much focuses on the main story line. There are no sidequests except maybe some ways to make money like bringing cars to the scrap heap and robbing shops/gasstations. 

The variations of cars is quite limited, as would be realistic around 1950. You can buy a few new clothes and guns but there was not one moment in the game where I actually needed to buy guns. The clothes come in handy whenever you are wanted with the police and have to change clothes. 
You can also bring a car to the garage to repaint it and change the license plate so the car is not wanted anymore. Customisation of cars is also quite limited and unnecessary. 

The story however is quite good. The game really feels like a Mafia movie, albeit with a lot of scenes directly stolen from the movies but that's fine by me. 

Currently I did not finish the remastered version of the game yet because of a game breaking bug at the end of chapter 14 where Joe as to go see a doctor. Somehow the game thought Vito was in the car , which he was not.... 

I could not kill myself so the only thing I could do is try to restart the game. This did not work because my savegame is broken which forces me to restart Chapter 14. This would be okay with me under normal circumstances but Chapter 14 is quite a long chapter with some annoying filler content. Also, I probably will not get the achievement for finishing Mafia II on hard mode.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review: Learning recently that Mafia I was going to be fully remastered and that Mafia II and Mafia III now had "Definitive Editions" that you would receive for free if you already owned both games, I was quite excited to see Mafia II, my favorite game on the PS3 next to Grand Theft Auto IV, be revamped for 2020. However, what I got was a complete letdown. Sure, the graphics and textures look better, as does some of the facial details and whatnot, but weapon sounds were changed when they didn't need to be, the cloth physics for clothes are gone unless you do some serious file digging to find them, and some songs were removed, as I noticed when Dean Martin's "Ain't That a Kick in the Head" didn't play during the credits for the main story. On top of that, even some graphical bugs still remain. During the cutscene for Chapter 9's mission "Balls and Beans" whenever it shows Luca interrogating Tony Balls and Harvey Beans, Beans's face is horribly glitched. Small items in the game such as cans on the street have glitchy shadows and textures as well. It really makes you wonder, was this seriously their best attempt at a remaster? Mafia II is 10+ years old, and even back when it first came out it looked great. To sum it all up, Mafia II:DE doesn't feel like a remaster at all, just an attempt to create an official Mafia title which in reality could just be classified as Mafia II with an ENB. You're much better off playing the OG Mafia II where everything is still there, as it should be, even if you don't have fancy-schmancy "improved" graphics.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
As a whole, I recommend this game. If you've played Mafia 2 before and want to take a nostalgic trip or newcomers to the franchise, it's worth playing. HOWEVER, there are some bugs. I've not come across any crashes or game breaking bugs so far, though there are a few graphical errors. Most notably for me would be things like the steam rising from grates on the street flickering, same as tyre smoke.

If you can look past the few graphical issues, the game itself is still as good as it ever was, and I've thoroughly enjoyed re-visiting this game after not playing for some years.

WINDOWS 7 USERS: If you get "Missing XINPUT1_4.DLL"  on startup, go to C:\Windows\System32 and copy the xinput1_3.dll file to steamapps\common\Mafia II Definitive Edition\pc and rename the file you copied to xinput1_4.dll 

TL:DR: Buy the original here if you don't have it already https://www.gog.com/game/mafia_ii_directors_cut  and only play this right now if you got it for free like a lot of us did.

Mafia II Definitive Edition is a tragic story of missed opportunities, the only real differences between this and the original game is some questionably improved graphical effects and texture work and sadly the introduction of new bugs the original didn't have (though I must say the snow on the pavements during winter is a great improvement.)  As well as forcing you to buy this one on steam if you want the original. (just go to GOG and buy it there.)

This could have been so much more, anyone who is interested heavily in the Mafia franchise is no doubt aware by now of how much content was cut from this game due to publisher pressure and time constraints, and this could have been a real opportunity to remedy that and let us see what could have been. This is made doubly sad by the fact that simply modding the original Mafia II will get you closer to this dream and look a bit nicer as well. 

They also missed the opportunity to integrate Joe's adventures into the main campaign like I always felt it should have been. 

With very little effort they could have vastly improved this game even if they didn't touch the graphics at all (and sometimes I wish they hadn't)   I can only hope that they will update this with some more content to justify it's horrible price tag but given how poorly Mafia III was delivered and how poorly this and the other definitive edition have been delivered I have gone from being hyped to suspicious of the upcoming Mafia I remake.

The bar is so low i didn't trip on it, i tripped on the hole it made in the floor. It was so hard to tell how the graphics had been updated, which is the only way it has been changed, that I had to go lookup a side by side comparison on youtube and even then it was hard to tell. Sure there is some prettier snow on the ground, which doesnt even make tracks in it when you move through it like in games that came out 6 years ago, but it isnt worth the huge loss in fps that comes with it. Don't even get me started on the character models. They are so low poly that you can see the separation lines, the main character's best friend Joe's cross looks like a tattoo and the hands look like they came from super mario 64. In my opinion, this remaster is so bad it casts a shadow over every other remaster that will be approaching in the near future. Let's hope they can make it up in the original mafia but im not holding my breath.

review: Whether you play the original or the remaster Mafia 2 is a masterpiece. Don't go in expecting GTA though, this game is more about story with some open world mechanics. And that open world is beautiful and and believable. The game starts in 1945 and theirs a 6 year time jump im not going to spoil and everything changes. the cars, the music, the clothes. The level of detail in this game is unbelievable. People go about their day on the street selling newspaper, go to their jobs with briefcases, shopping, moving boxes at the docks or just drinking in the gutter they will even sometimes slip on ice. Cops will pull you over and give you a ticket for not following the speed limit, you're car can run out of gas, gas tanks explode like real life if shot, tons of little immersion touches but it dosent go as far as the orginal Mafia in these aspect. Cops will put your face in the newspaper if you getaway and get your licesnce plate number so you also have to keep that in mind and change your clothing and buy a new licensce plate. If Martin Scorsese directed a video game it would be MAFIA 2. The characters are all likeable and believable and the story is full of twist and turns. The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, the original scores go perfectaly with the bleakness of the story and theirs all your favorite classic oldies from the 40s and 50s on the radio. Personally I prefer the defenitive edition changes as I played this game multiple times on the 360 and im glad to see it get a fresh brush of paint and some new content, even if it is just some clothes and some cars. The new lighting system, 4k textures, face remodeling and the general improvements all make this game pass for a 2020 game. It hasn't age a bit, even the original at max settings, still holds up. 9.5/10

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
This one has been on my radar since it was released but I never got around to checking it out.  I picked the non "Definitive" version last year for six bucks and change and recently got this sent to me for free so I figured I'd give it a spin.

While I've played worse games, this one is aggressively mediocre in every way that the whole experience ends up being forgettable before it's even done.  I can only really suggest this if 1.) you're really into this setting and 2.) you can get it for cheap, thirty bucks is too high a price by far.

Normally open world games like this start off boring with a battery of pointless tutorial missions that recap mechanics that everyone is already familiar with from dozens of other titles, but here the beginning of where the game peaks.  The snowy 1940s NYC of the opening chapters looks great and the licensed period music only adds to the charm.  These missions are a mix of simple hand to hand combat, stealth, shooting and driving, all stuff you'd expect.  You'll be beating up uncooperative dockworkers, selling bootleg cigarettes, and shooting cookie cutter mooks for 4-5 hours.  Again none of this is revelatory but starting off with these small jobs both introduces you to the mechanics and helps solidify your place at the bottom of the criminal underworld of Empire Bay.

The thing is, once you've gotten through these opening chapters and the game progresses you realize it has NOTHING to offer besides what you've already seen.  Rather than introduce anything new, all of the above mechanics just became more of a hassle to deal with.  Driving around, which is charming at first given the old timey setting and cars, quickly becomes your primary activity, as you chauffeur NPCs from end of the completely empty map to the other, then drive all the way BACK across that empty map to your house so that you can end the chapter by walking up two or three flights of stairs, entering your empty apartment that has nothing you can interact with, and press X next  to your bed.  Shooting is even worse - this game's cover-based combat would have been bland by 2010 standards.  As the chapters progress the only difference is that the game puts you up against large numbers of bullet sponge enemies who can shred your health to nothing in short order if you dare leave cover, often from areas you can't even see.   Memorizing the scripted enemy spawns through trial and error is basically your only option to get through late game combat encounters, especially because you can't adjust difficulty mid-game to just get through the more maddening bits.

But it gets worse - a lot of the games features seem at odds with other design choices.  There are weapon stores throughout the game that you can spend your money at to get gear... but the game regularly will take your weapons away from you at random intervals.  Stocking up before a combat heavy mission is often pointless because the designer didn't design the encounter with you having them in mind.  You can spend your money on vehicle upgrades... but the maddening decision to include a speed limit negates the benefit of having a faster car.  Not that owning a car is of much benefit - you'll almost always be driving an NPC's vehicle which is almost always a piece of crap instead of your highly upgraded cars which largely gather dust in your garage.  You can spend money on outfits, but there's a point mid-game where all of your possessions, those included, are also removed.  Any attempt to spend your time doing ANYTHING besides the story missions, in order, immediately, is rendered pointless.  You can crush cars at the junkyard and rob stores to get money, sure, but why?  It's basically worthless (except, of course, at one point late in the game where you have to raise funds by repeating those two activities, over and over again.  I liked this part because it let me catch up on podcasts while I mindlessly picked the locks of cars, drove them into the crusher, walked up the stairs to the crusher controls, hit X to crush the car, etc etc).

But my biggest gripe is the checkpointing system.  This is the WORST example of this I have ever seen in a modern game, bar none.  The game has no manual saves to speak of and doesn't save when you quit.  The only way for it to save is at predetermined intervals during story missions.  So, if you do get the crazy idea in your head to go check out the world, raise some cash perhaps, and then, say, die in a car accident, you're back to the last checkpoint which could have been an hour ago.  The game punishes you at every turn for trying to do anything other than the story.  I know that it's lazy in a way to compare this to other open world games and complain that it doesn't do what they do, but the game invites these comparisons by trying to copy the open world urban game format and force a linear shooter in to it.

Let's end with the story, which is often touted as the games best feature.  This is the only thing the game pulls off, for me, and even then it's nothing special.  It's your basic rags to riches and then back to rags story of a dude who always wanted to be a gangster.  Every cliche you've seen in mob fiction is represented here and played straight without a hint of irony or subversion.  Vito is well voice acted and the new model for him looks great but it doesn't fix the fact that he's a cardboard cutout protagonist with no agency who has nothing driving him besides a desire for money and the fact that there's no game if he doesn't do the things the story needs him to do.  Every single thing that's asked of him he does without question or introspection and it's impossible to relate to him or his struggles.  Every other character is like that but worse.  I have a special hatred for Joe, who may be the most detestable sidekick character I've seen yet in any game. [spoiler]When he's carted away to be murdered at the end,  I had the only actual moment of emotional resonance in the entire experience, and it was one of happiness that this annoying character was going to be offed.  The idea that this is some tear-jerking moment is laughable to me.[/spoiler].

Overall, I'm glad I didn't spend thirty dollars on this.  If you're really hard up for an old timey gangster game and don't mind it being a boring slog that has no respect for your time, go for it.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia 2 a game I hold near and dear to my heart, I personally hail it as one of the best narrative driven stories, while linear it is still a game that holds up to this day and is much better than the mess that is Mafia 3, now that I am done tooting the horn of Mafia 2 I will talk about the changes to the game from it's classic edition to now. Mafia 2 Definitive Edition definitely has some problems, more so on console to my knowledge but this isn't about the console port this is about the PC version.

The remaster problem: The graphics on some characters look gorgeous, Joe, Henry, Vito and the other big players within Empire Bay look nothing short of amazing as with some of the set pieces as well looking beautiful however there is a drawback with this in which not everyone in Empire Bay got the special treatment and thus they still look about the same as they do in Mafia 2, for a remaster this isn't a very good thing however as someone who has played through Mafia 2 many times it was a slight annoyance to see a bunch of NPC's look like they do and have Vito look great. A lot of Empire Bay also is very beautiful to look at you can tell there was definitely some passion put behind remastering the game however sadly some of the passion was put into one area and ignored in another.

The story: Mafia 2 follows the story of Vittorio Antonio "Vito" Scaletta born in Sicily in 1925, his parents moved him and his sister to America to start a new life, in 1943 he was arrested during a heist with his buddy Joe and given a choice, go to prison or fight in World War 2, after returning from the war in 1945 he meets back up with Joe who gets him out of the service and working with him, Vito after finding out the debt his family has sets out for a life of crime with Joe in order to pay back his family and himself so as to never make the same mistakes his father did. This is just a basic synopsis I wrote up for the start of the game's plot, the story of Mafia 2 while a bit cliche holds up extraordinarily well telling an emotional story of a man who originally set out to help his own family ended up becoming deeply involved in the Mafia life.

The gameplay: Mafia 2 Definitive Edtion's gameplay is the same as it is in Mafia 2, some people call it outdated which is true as it's still the same as it was in 2010, a little clunky but I think it holds up quite well. Each gun brings something a little different, the 1911 is the perfect all rounder handgun to use, the .38 is the weakest of the bunch but fires quite fast, the c96 boasts the most bullets out of all of them and the magnum is the strongest, the shotgun is one of the best weapons for close to medium levels of combat and the Thompson M1A1 is a great all rounder machine gun only rivalled by it's big brother the Thompson 1928, there are other guns that can fill in different roles for each scenario so it is fun to experiment and see which one will suit you best, however keep in mind that some of these guns you won't be able to come by very early on in the game with the exception of Chapter 1 when you are fighting in World War 2. The driving hasn't seen much change either, don't speed around the city otherwise you will be chased by cops unless you know the car you are using will outrun the any day.

Glitches that I know of: currently with Mafia 2 Definitive Edition I know of a few glitches in the game, one of them being a texture glitch with some litter on the ground having broken textures and I believe I am the only one who has encountered  this glitch so far but in the cutscenes for the end of Chapter 10 and part of the cutscenes in Chapter 11 would abruptly end before they were supposed to, these don't affect me too much as I have already finished the game many times however these can be a massive problem for players who are just starting out in the game, if this was just something that happened to me then it is okay but hopefully if it does happen to others it will be patched out soon, the last glitch is just a goofy one in which during cutscenes Vito's head would clip through his hat or his hat would clip through his head, it was funny to see that happen from time to time but it should be patched out somewhat soon so as not to take anyone out of the cutscenes. 

The only other problem I noticed with the game is that during the main story pretty much every coat that should have physics with it would just stick to Vito, there appears to be a mod that patches this out already so use that if you want while we wait for it to be patched out, this problem does not occur in the DLC though for some reason.

In conclusion Mafia 2 Definitive Edition is what many would consider a true remaster, it updates the games visuals and makes it playable on next gen consoles, this is a pretty good PC remaster but a horrendous one on console according to the problems it has, my advice would be to pick this game up if you are interested in an old school Mafia story or get the bundle to get them all, however you need to make your voice be heard if you are encountering glitches to 2k or through reviews to get them patched out.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Let me start by saying that Mafia 2 is my favourite game of all time. I finished it multiple times on Xbox 360, same with the PS3, and probably another 2 or 3 times on PC. Add to that that I've just finished this version of the game and i think i can safely say I've played my fair share of this game. The most disappointing part of this edition is that the bug on the objective "pay Bruno back" which results in an infinite loading screen or the door not being usable at all, is still present in this version of the game. It's been in the "classic" version since launch and is still present in this version, not very "definitive" at all.

The graphics updates to this game are nice, although subtle and in no way an upgrade that makes the game "next gen"
This version comes will all the DLC packs so thats a bonus, plus it was free to owners of the "classic" version. 
The story of Mafia 2 itself is great and is something that blows away Mafia 3 in every single way.
If you're tempted to play Mafia 3 and haven't played this, don't bother with Mafia 3. This game is superior in every way.

I recommend playing this version of the game if you've had it for free, as the game itself is brilliant, but the fact that bugs that have been in the game since its 2010 launch is honestly disappointing

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Okay, let me start by getting this out of the way:
Mafia II is a phenomenal game, in so many ways.. If you haven't played it already, then play it!

But, if you already have played it... Do n't expect to be blown away, as the remaster is crap.

1)  some of the licensed music was removed... which RUINS the 1950's atmosphere; half the songs we sang along to as we cruised around Empire Bay are no more.
2) Okay, MOSTLY the texture quality was increased, as was the lighting-- but I've noticed so many instances of lights flickering, decals Z-Fighting constantly (flickering between the decal and the texture beneath as the camera doesn't know which to render on top),  texture pop-in, and remember I used the word "mostly"? Well, there are still loads of textures that haven't been touched-- these look even more apparent as everything around them has been improved.
3) PhysX (Or lack thereof). The phenomenal physics of the original 2010 game aren't entirely present-- some debris effects seem to be intact, but a lot has been removed-- cloth physics seem to have been removed entirely, making Vito's coat stiff as a board. Unrealistic, and super annoying as his coat physics were one of the first things I'd praise about the original after the story xD
4) THE EYES, like wtf... Characters' eyes are completely fixed in position. This completely ruins the mannerisms of characters like Henry in particular.  They are more detailed eyes though, texture wise, and they reflect the environment quite well, if only they actually f*cking moved!
5) None of the cut content. This was a real annoyance. Many people would have hoped to see the cut content, but none of it is here. It's a shame as I'm sure that alone would've made all my points so far easy to ignore.

Again, it's a phenomenal game, but this remaster is not so good... Play the original-- I'm sure there are "graphics mods" out there if you wish for a more modern look.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
[list] [h1]🔹Positive Aspects:[/h1]
[*]Great HD Textures improving Empire bay and its characters .
[*]You get all the previous DLCs for free plus some new ones.
[*]Performance improved.
[*]Major lighting improvements.

[h1]🔸Negative Aspects:[/h1]
[*]Some minor bugs still present.


[h1]▶️Introduction[/h1]
Mafia 2 is a third person open world game with a strong emphasis on storytelling. This is the successor of Mafia 1 which was one of the best games of the early 2000s. As we all know by now Mafia 2 was a worthy successor in 2010 but how does the HD Remaster stack up? Lets take a look. Mafia 2 Definitive Edition was developed by Hangar 13 and d3t and published by [url=https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/2K]2K.[/url]

Release Date : 19th May 2020 (Mafia 2, 23rd August 2010).
Last known update: 19th May 2020.


[h1]🎮Gameplay:[/h1]

[b]Are there any changes as far as gameplay goes?[/b]

[list] [*] [b]Mission design and shooting :[/b]
If you think Mafia 2 is just another ‘’copy’’ game of Grand Theft Auto you’re totally wrong, the Mafia series really takes the time to make you familiar with controls, movement and shooting, it is a slow paced third person game that sometimes might need a little bit of tactical movement. Mafia makes great use of the run and cover system and enemies usually die within a couple of shots, now level design was great in Mafia 2 as every mission had a different meaning and different way of completing. The level design of Mafia was actually ahead of its time, sadly mechanics weren’t and the game still feels a little rusty and slow compared to Mafia 3 that does actually have the mechanics as it is a much newer game. So in short, no they did not change anything and I like that decision as it keeps the purity of the game quite high.

[*] [b]Open world potential:[/b]
Granted Mafia 2 didn’t possess a huge man in 2010 and in today’s time it is worse, still the city of Empire Bay is extremely detailed with a lot of potential, the NPC and randomly generated humans in the streets of Empire Bay feel alive, for example in the snow timeline of the game you could see random people falling due to the icy roads and this honestly adds a crazy level of detail that is even by today's standards unmatched.Now as far as special events go you basically get nothing, you cannot race your cars not can you play quicktime missions which is kind of lackluster as far as stores and what you can do with your money you get a plethora of options  like boutique stores, vehicle garages and even gun shops.

[*] [b]Weather and other little details:[/b]
Weather and nighttime are actually working real time in the game, out of nowhere it might start raining and the rain is actually noticeable while driving, that's pretty rare for an open world story game that doesn’t really focus on driving that much. After your cars break down due to multiple fatal hits you can actually go out and repair it yourself just like in the 1950s. Lastly you heal yourself by consuming food and you even get custom cutscenes for this which is a great attention to detail.
[/list]


[h1]📚Story:[/h1]
You have been warned, spoilers ahead.

Vito Scarletta is the main character and his story starts back in Sicily when his parents decided to avoid the WW2 italian drama and travel to Empire Bay, USA. Vito was both fascinated and disgusted by the city and had to learn the language in order to keep on surviving there.After some years Vito crossed paths with Joe Barbarro and both of them started robbing small shops together as money was low. One day Vito gets caught and gets to the chance to fight for the American army in 1943 in order to defeat Italy. Vito then comes back after an injury in 1945 and after that his mob career took on. First Vito was working for the Clemente family in which he proved useful but after someone snitched on him during the gas stamp mission vito had to serve jail time. While in jail Vito got to know strong people like Leo Galante and obviously joined the Galante prison gang. After proving that Vito is a viable option Galante got Vito out of prison right after Galante took Exit. After being a Free man Vito had only his sister as his mother died while he was a prisoner. Joe offered Vito a spot to work for the Falcone family and Vito happily accepted without seeing the bigger picture, after some breathtaking mission killing former boss Clemente, witnessing Henry's death by the Empire Bay Triads under the command of Mr.Wong and more Vito realises that Falcone wanted to kill all the other Bosses in order to sell Dope freely. In order to combat that Vito had to kill Falcone as Leo Galante ordered Vito to do in order to save himself from all the other families and the Feds.


[h1]🌇Graphics / Audio:[/h1]
As mentioned above Mafia 2 got major texture and lighting improvements. Most of the noticeable improvements come within cutscenes where you can clearly see a lot more detail on the skin and hair of character and even their eyes look normal now compared to the OG version. Lighting and textures and even minor geometry fixes are noticeable within EMpire bay.

[list] [*] [b]Graphics:[/b]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2106316671

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2106317139

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2104172198

[*] [b]Audio / Soundtrack:[/b]
Audio is a mixed bag in my opinion. cars do sound just a tad bit better but gunshots are pretty flat in the remaster while the OG version had quite the kick still, Voice actors are still the same and I think that the soundtrack hasn’t lost any songs which is always a plus as the music in the game is just amazing.

[/list]

[h1]🌀Performance:[/h1]
[b]The Remaster works better on High end devices but worse on Low end ones. [/b]
Here are the Benchmark stats of both the Remaster and the OG version.

AMD Ryzen 5 3600 X
16GB RAM
Nvidia RTX 2070 Super

1920x1080 ultra settings, on the remaster  the device gets major improvements.

8GB RAM 
Intel HD 5500 1GB

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2106561518

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2106572755


800x600 Low-Med Settings, on the remaster the device suffers a lot.

[list]
[*] [b]In Game:[/b]
AMD Ryzen 5 3600 X, 16GB RAM, RTX 2070 S: Mostly 144fps on ultra settings while normally playing.

Intel Core i5 5200U, 8GB RAM, Intel HD 5500:Mostly about 28fps on Low-Med while normally playing.

[*] [b]🖥️Bugs / Glitches / Crashes:[/b]
In 12 hours of being an Italian mafia boy I had no crashes but minor bugs, for example PhysX wasn’t working on my Coat and I had to do some fixes, lighting bugs and even magazines vanishing. Other than that I had a great and stable experience.


[/list]

[h1]💲Price:[/h1]
If you had Mafia 2 you get the Remaster for free.
Great Value.
29,99Eur. is a little too much, I would wait for a sale.

[h1]⚖️Conclusion:[/h1]
Mafia 2 Definitive Edition is a more than solid remaster as it does give you all the DLCs and improves a lot as far as graphics go yet it still has some minor technical problems which is not really optimal, if you can ignore that you get a hell of a game though.

[h1]📉Overall rating: 90/ 100 [/h1]

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
I cant give this a thumbs down as it's free if you own Mafia 2, and you cant really complain about something you got for free unless its a sexually transmitted disease. 

The new textures and lighting are very nice, and the indoor environments are lovely for such an old game. Some of the character models are pretty woeful looking tho, especially the "sexy" ladies Joe kicks out of his apartment in the first act, they look like something out of Unreal 2, and all the characters eyes look really weird at times too, like theyve all got really puffy, wrinkled eyelids.
The actual gameplay is the exact same and thats the biggest disappointment to be honest. 3rd person shooting is fairly weak feeling, the guns don't feel punchy or powerful, the aiming is loose and overall its just about serviceable. The driving is okay too, and really those are the only two things you do in the entire game. Oh that, and an insta fail stealth section or two. So yeah. Fun shit like that.

The story is...eh. The writing and voice acting is all very "eyyy youse guys, lets go boost a cah and slap around some fooken broads", that is to say its about as cliched and stereotypical as you can get for a story based on the Mob in the 1940's. 

I dont think Mafia 2 as a game, or as a story, has aged particularly well, and some new textures and lighting doesnt really help all that much. If you really want to replay Mafia 2, just play the old version thats about 1.99 in every sale and dont spend 30 bucks on this.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Loved Mafia and Mafia II. I think it's pretty cool that people who owned the original version of the game already, were given this for free, but if I hadn't been then I probably wouldn't have spent the money that they're asking for it.

The retextures do look absolutely awesome, but funnily enough, their doing this has made it super obvious where they decided not to retexture things, which is a decision they made, and it makes the whole thing feel really half-arsed, at least to me.

It's not all bad though, like I said, the retextured things do look really nice, and the improvements they made to sounds and sound quality are also really appreciated. I do intend to play this game through to completion because I do love Mafia II, but I wouldn't feel good spending $30 for what ultimately seems to be a half-arsed remaster, when I could get the same fantastic game, but less pretty, for less money.

If you've never played Mafia II, don't be suckered by "Definitive Edition" or the claims of "Stunning HD detail", the classic version is worth every penny, and still holds up in 2020.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II: Definitive Edition: Soft Around The Edges

Right, this was something that really came out of nowhere, a "Definitive Edition" lineup for the three main Mafia games. I mean I expected 2K to do something special for the release of the Mafia I Remaster but this was out of nowhere and not in a good way. I feel bad for Hangar 13 in a sense, they always seem to get ambushed with all of the heavy lifting for stuff like this. Mafia II: DE is a weird remaster that doesn't do much to the game and does enough things wrong that the only reason I'm not more pissed off is that 2K gave this for free to anyone who owned Mafia II before hand.

I'm going to break from my traditional formula to just get into the nitty gritty, you know the story already, it's Mafia II. In-general, the remaster looks exactly the same as it originally did with a slightly cleaner texture pack but there's a feeling that a couple of extra fingers got stapled to this Frankenstein's monster without checking if the monster could use it. Besides the 2K Account thing, everything about the game is just slightly off.

Guns don't sound like they do, voices tend to sound different, stuff like PhysX seem to be broken and the game's ability to even run right runs a line between functional and absolutely broken that I have "luckily" found myself on the functioning side. Relatively. As for the other sales points for this, yeah it includes all of the DLC for 20 dollars. That's not TOO bad if the game actually ran correctly but from my playthrough, which even then seems to be an outlier from most people having a full on broken game, this definitely needed more time to proof before 2K went to bake it.

TL:DR: If you want Mafia II, play the "Classic" version that you can find elsewhere for the time being. I have a feeling 2K will at the very least attempt to clean this version up but we're still a decent bit away from that bit of magic happening. It's Mafia II, all the crime and chaos that entails with a few weird additions and a HUGE jump in GB takeup to make you consider waiting on this. It's usually a bad sign when you get a game like this for free and you still feel sour about it. Come on 2K, try a little harder and stop forcing your companies to shove these games out of the door and maybe then you'll beat Rockstar to the punch rather than playing second fiddle.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
When I heard about the Mafia Trilogy being remasterd, Mafia 2 wasn't my first thought, I thought about the wonderful and underrated Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven, then I heard we were getting Mafia 2 remastered three months before the first one, so why not go back to it again ?

In all honesty, the original game has aged well, even 10 years later it still looks pretty good considering the technology. Mafia II : Definitive Edition keeps things fresh thanks to newer texture and shadows. But that's pretty much all you'll get from this edition.

The game is still infected with bugs all over the place, from weird AI to visual glitches. Outside of that, the game feels like the original, meaning you'll still get this great campaign with this underlying feeling that they cut so much content out of this wonderful game. Should you play it again ? Of course, but don't expect it to be the Mafia II we were supposed to get years ago.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Got it for free, which I sure do appreciate.  That's a good thing too, because I am disappointed.  It looks like this was quickly ported over from DX9 to DX11 API with a few general enhancements (textures, lighting, etc.) by D3T.  Unfortunately, there are many technical bugs present right now in this port.  It seems that QA testing was either slim or non-existent.

Here's a quick list of bugs I have personally seen happen and/or confirmed from multiple reports from others:
-Physx API is broken.  It's really bad.  Physx is always on, with no option to turn it off, and it's extremely buggy.  Vito (your character) has 0 physx applied to coats, leaving them looking like old PS2 style graphics with the bottom sticking to Vito's legs.  This can be worked around though, by deleting the physx files which enables the back-up physics engine (much simpler cloth physics, comparable to 360 version of classic edition)
-Audio is bugged and cutscenes only go through the left speaker.  You can work around this by setting audio to high and to stereo, although that is a poor workaround for people with surround sound setups.
-Hitching is pretty bad, but I remember the Classic version had similar hitching.  This is likely due to the old engine being overly conservative back in the day.  The engine loads chunks of the world frequently when traveling through the world, causing the hitching(even installing on an SSD didn't help).  This adds to my suspicion of quick port of the Classic version.  I ran Special K and used it's more advanced framerate limiter, in order to normalize frametimes and minimize some loading hitching.
-Smoke and other alpha effects flicker now.  I have seen reports that limiting to 60 FPS corrects this, however this is a bad workaround in the days of Gsync/Freesync monitors.  I personally limit to 60 in single player controller games anyways, but this seems like yet another oversight from the port job.
-There a plenty more, but these are the most frequent I have seen or have experienced myself.  Just look at the other reviews, and you'll probably see many more bugs like special characters causing save issues (Silent, creator the the GTA SilentPatch's, is creating a patch for this as I speak, he knows far more about the issue than me).


I would really avoid buying this RIGHT NOW.  Keep your eyes out for a patch though, if D3T can continue supporting it then it will be even better than the original Mafia 2, which holds a special place in my heart.

D3T, if you see this, you're up to bat!!!  This is your chance to redeem yourself, until then I simply cannot recommend buying this version as it is fundamentally broken.  If this changes and you patch it, I will adjust my review :)

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review: This is an unfortunate release. So much could have been great, and so much is wrong. I’ll start off on a positive note, that being that the few things which have changed for the better are great. Wonderful remastered character models/faces, nice looking lighting, and the updates to *certain* textures look great too. But all in all, this ‘remaster’ is just disappointing. So much of the game is glossed over, so many areas that could benefit from new assets or ported assets from Mafia 3, so many areas that could’ve used brand new textures rather than old upscaled ones, and so many situations that could areas that could have more modern effects added, like snowdrifts or summer leaves blowing in the wind. The other big disappointment is just how much this remaster breaks. PhysX has been gutted from the game making 80% of the clothing and physics/cloth enabled objects from the original simply not work, or not function to the degree it used to. Certain effects like sewer steam is broken and jittery. I’ve even see vertex’s in some cases become completely stiff, causing objects to weirdly stretch and solidify while the rest is moving (another great example of broken clothes). This really is the absolute bare minimum they could have done for a remaster, and they would have been better off just releasing and HD texture pack or something of the sort for free. I personally did not buy this remaster and received it for free as an owner of the original Mafia 2, but if you’re considering buying this, I really don’t think the changes justify it. Too little for too high a price, and too many key components broken. Oh, and on a closing note, the ported Lincoln Clay outfit looks horrendous, the least you could have done for that is fit it to Vito’s body type, or fix the very obvious neck seam due to Vito and Lincoln having completely separate textures.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
I played Mafia 2 when it originally came out around a decade ago, and it was always on my mind to play again someday.  But like so many games, I never found time to go back to it, and once you are multiple generations of graphics past, it becomes even more difficult to go back to.

So I was quite surprised when I was just looking through my library and saw that the "Definitive" edition had just been released a handful of days ago, and it had automatically been added to my account since I already had the original version.

I downloaded the 38gb install and played for an hour, the first time since something like 2010 I had played Mafia 2.  

I play on an ultra wide monitor, resolution of 3840x1600, and I was happy to see that the game supports this resolution and that it was automatically selected.  So far so good.

Graphics wise the textures aren't too bad while playing the game, but something feels "off" about the character movement.  I don't know if it was always like that, or I'm just too used to playing GTA5 and RDR2 and how the movement mechanics work in those games.  Or maybe it's the animations/character models themselves that do not move right.  Aside from that, I enjoyed the first hour, and I believe I will indeed do that second play-through of the game.

One note about cut-scenes, they do not appear to have been upgraded, and look much worse than the game does while playing.

I have had no bugs or oddities within the first hour of the game, for what it's worth.

[b]Since you get a free copy of the original, I'm going to recommend.[/b] If this was a stand alone version, I would not recommend.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
There's a lot this remaster does well, but as of launch, there is a whole lot that needs fixing.
At least original owners got this free! If they expected us to rebuy the game in this state, this launch would have been REALLY bad.

The new lighting and texture work is overall great, no complaints about that. As for some more important things though...

Now for the issues that I've noticed that need to be fixed:
1. Cloth physics are bugged in the main game. All the physics but cloth work fine, the cloth is stuck at the lowest quality setting from the original no matter what setting you use here. It works fine in the DLCs. Probably just a bug, but please don't ignore this one and leave it unpatched, the main game looks like absolute crap without cloth physics. And don't just stop at the old medium physics setting, give us the full PhysX cloth physics from the original back. Some other issues with cloth include the physics spazzing out and making odd jutting shapes, which happened in the original but is more common now. I assume it's something to do with the cloth physics being bugged in general, so if the botched physics in this remaster are repaired to their original game state, all of this might go away.

2. Some effects like smoke can now flicker and stutter. This is a very noticeable issue that wasn't in the original game, it's distracting and needs fixing ASAP.

3.Light flicker, on streetlamps and distant buildings, was present in the original but is now more noticable, possibly because of the revamped lighting. It would be nice to get a fix, but since this was an original issue, it could be a fundamental engine problem, so I won't be mad if it's not fixed.

4. Some textures that really need high-res versions still use old textures. The biggest offender is the rock texture. Now that the mountains have been made more rocky and rocks are way closer to you up on the roads, they really need to be sharper because they're so visible. Not essential to fix, but would be appreciated.

5. The eyes. Characters look overall great, but for some odd reason they removed the moving eyes from the original cutscenes, now they blink whenever their eyes change direction, and the eyes are in a new direction when they open, we no longer see them move. Some characters don't even move their eyes, no blinking or anything, they just stare blankly ahead the whole cutscene. It really makes the characters less expressive and more robotic. The fact that they covered some of this up with blinking shows that they were aware that they somehow messed it up, and instead of fixing it they tried to hide it, and didn't even do a good job at that since half the characters simply don't look anywhere but forward now. Really disappointing intentional corner-cutting, stuff like this is why I don't respect Hangar 13 that much. Take the time to do it right, you messed up something that already worked, now fix it. As with the cloth physics, just make it like the original again, copy and paste the old animations into the remaster if you have to, I can't imagine why this would be an issue short of a dumb typo or something.

If Hangar 13 fails to fix the three most important issues that they messed up from the original: the physics, flickering smoke, and eye animations, I will not buy the Mafia 1 Remastered or the future Mafia IV if they develop it. I can let III's issues slide because that was their first game of that size. But breaking things that already worked in the original Mafia II, putting shoddy bandaids on them or ignoring them entirely instead of fixing them, and releasing the remaster knowing these things are broken, is a pretty bad look that shows just how little they care. If they don't fix all three of those issues, I'm done with them.

And I know they shipped it out to another company to remaster; but since they obviously chose someone that wasn't up to the job, received a remaster that was visibly not up to par, and released it without fixing any of the new issues anyway, they might as well have broken it themselves. 

After many of Mafia III's still-present issues and now this, Hangar 13 needs to prove to the community that they care about quality by fixing this remaster. How they treat this game with patches after launch is going to be the deciding factor in whether I buy any future game with their name attached to it. The community's good will matters more than they might think; Mafia III's sales were underwhelming because of all its issues and that can happen again. If they keep messing up, the series is either going to permanently end, or get passed off to another developer that's up to the task. In short, either do the community right for once and fix some bugs, or I and many others are out.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Honestly, I'm disappointed,

When I saw the announcements for a remaster of one of my favorite games of all time, I was thrilled to say the least. In short, this is a purely graphical remaster that often makes the game look even worse than the original. It's not polished at all. This is something you would expect a free mod to pull off. 

Perhaps I'm being harsh, when you set out to make a remaster of a masterpiece and charge 30 euros for the thing, you'd expect it to be built from the ground up, something that could compete with 2020 graphics while staying true to the original. This remaster completely fails at that. It's literally just Mafia 2 with some mild adjustments. 

I honestly really hope they fix it, and I really really hope that this doesn't reflect how the Mafia 1 remaster is going to turn out in any way, this is a joke.

If this product was free to get I wouldn't be writing this review, even better, if it was a mod I wouldn't be writing this review. The fact you get this product for free if you have the original Mafia 2 does NOT make this any more acceptable. 

If you want to play Mafia 2 with better graphics, install a mod and save yourself the 33 GB download and the 30 euro price tag if you don't already own Mafia 2.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Garbage giant crosshairs and tiny FOV, we meet again.

In 2010 there were two versions of Mafia II. One for PC, the other for consoles. Now there is one with less features than before. Yay, parity!

I read nothing about this before release in the hope that it'd be a worthy remaster. They didn't even bother to redo the text/fonts - it's still blurry and low res. No FOV slider or anything else that would make a nice, modern difference. Plain old laziness. The only difference I can see is with the lighting, distant objects and textures, but even some of those are worse in comparison. I had little faith in the new Mafia game coming in August, now I have even less.

FYI to anyone who wants to persist with this game, you can change the FOV by manually editing files:

https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Mafia_II:_Definitive_Edition

To get crosshairs that aren't made for giant TVs, in this [u][b]PC GAME[/b][/u], you can use the following mod:

https://www.moddb.com/downloads/mafia-2-better-crosshairs-filthy

Personally, I'd stick with the 2010 version and those mods, there are less issues.

I had been enjoying the visuals and revisiting one of my favorite games until I made it to chapter 5 where you use the buzzsaw. The building that the shootout takes place in had my framerate dropping the further I made it into the level. I even turned down my settings and resolution and still was getting 23 frames. title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
TL;DR It's still  Mafia 2. One of my favorite games of ALL TIME. 

So, yeah, the game itself is amazing. It's worth picking up if you've never played the original. Those looking for an actual "remaster" will be disappointed. All the weird jankiness of the original (due to it being a game from 2010) is still there. Gunplay feels sloppy, the AI isn't very intelligent, and the car handling can be spotty. Really, the only thing that stands out is the updated lights and post-processing. 

The textures are still pretty low-res and pop-in is absolutely TERRIBLE. Pop-in actually seems worse since the fancy new lights will pop in when the cars do so it really draws your eyes to it.

Honestly, I wish they'd had just reworked the view-distance and tightened up the shooting since Mafia 2 "Classic" actually still holds up really well.

I guess I'm sad since it's a wasted opportunity.

BUT STILL. Don't let that deter you. A great game will always be a great game, so you might as well play a great game that looks a bit better than it did at release. Playing it now really puts into perspective how ahead of the time the game was. 

Plus there are really good... collectibles...

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Dont see why people are s h i t talking the game, Its just the same as the "classic" version 

Has the same bugs as before & same issues as before. Hell before i could not even play the classic version cause the game would be pitch black & no texture would load. So this is a big upgrade from the previous version to me. 

Is it perfect? No. The textures are obviously from the older version & some thing has not been fixed that should have been fixed. Did i expect a full on re-master of the game? LOL no. It does not need one. 

To review the [b] ACTUAL [/b] game. 

The story is great & the gun play is okay. Driving is fine & dialogue is decent. If you are expecting some sort of GTA style then look the other way cause you wont find it here. 

You can buy guns & you can buy new outfits. 
You can go to a bar & go to a diner to eat/drink other than that the game has not much to offer other than a really REALLY good story. Cannot stress this enough. I have always played trough the Mafia games once a year cause the story always brings me back & makes me want to play it again even if sometimes the story gets a bit [i] boring [/i] but it picks up again quickly. 

At the moment i have not tried any of the DLC's to  really put my opinion on them but the fact that they are included in the [b] base [/b] game is a fantastic deal especially when the DLC's combined were like $30. 

Is it worth buying if you dont own the classic version? [b] YES [/b] is it worth buying if i'm expecting a GTA Open world style game? [b] NO [/b] the game has an open world but its rather limited to what you do. Since the [i] open world [/i] is tied to the story it will keep reminding you to get to an location. There was a mod for the classic version that basically puts you in an open world but i dont think it works with this version. 

Its my favorite game of all time & the [i] Definitive Edition [/i] just puts a quick coat of new paint ontop of the classic version. 

9.5/10 - Could have been a better [i] "Remaster" [/i] but i cant complain at least this version works.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
This review comes from someone who beat the main story only.

When I heard about the game getting an update, I was excited to revisit a game I grew up playing. I honestly jumped in to try an see what all the complaints were about so I could give my 2 cents and try to defend a game I love. 

After playing through the story, I can say that there is some issues that ruin the game immersion-wise. Sections of the game had AI huddled in corners doing nothing. Some scenes had dwarfed faces during important dialogue which was sad to see. Some lighting also broke in certain points of the game. I liked how they updated the textures and made the game look great, but it looks like (to me) they use the same meshes for characters and buildings. Which is not a big deal to me personally, I just want to make that known to those who think the game is completely remade from the ground up. 

At the end of the day, I would still recommend the game for it's amazing story and fun game-play. My only reason I would recommend this version of the game is if you can deal with the bugs and want the nice updated visuals. Otherwise I suggest playing the classic version. Same thing but less buggy.

This review is based on release. Hopefully they are able to patch the issues I and many others ran into. This is a great game in the trilogy.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Mafia II as a game itself is fantastically good an immersive affair with engaging story and interesting characters with incredible atmosphere and jaw dropping attention to detail but you probably already knew that. 

However this Definitive edition manages to introduce a host of new visual glitches (such as character models clipping through clothes, eyes of npcs as well as player character sometimes get locked in a certain position starring into abyss, textures exude a stretching effect and more noticeable pop ins of objects) none of which were present in the Classic edition on top of that frame rate seems to be about as stable as a skateboard in a canoe. Support for 4k resolution and sharper textures are a welcome edition however there are mods that provide that for free and do a better job at that. It is difficult to tell what has been changed without having a side by side comparison sometimes.

Major positive for this however is that the owners of the original copy of Mafia II got the "Definitive" edition for free for if I had to pay for this i would have refunded it by now. Heres hoping that these issues will be ironed out through patchwork, however this botched job of Mafia II has me somewhat worried for the original Mafia remaster as its the same company Hangar 13 who are working on it. Heres hoping they dont screw that up.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
While the core of Mafia II and the Definitive Edition are solid, Mafia II: Definitive Edition is a clear cash grab with little return. The gameplay is still very much the same and intact, the game runs smoothly and story is still decently average.

The "Definitive Edition" version of Mafia II is basically just an modern upscaling of the regular game. You will notice very little difference if you've played the original Mafia II and even if you haven't, it still looks like a game of it's time (2010). Save your $30 and wait for the Mafia 1 Remake or wait for a sale.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
tldr: Just buy Mafia 2 (Classic)

How it stands as a graphical remaster;
Pros:
Updated for the Mafia 3 engine (64 bit, better general performance on modern machines)
More graphical options
Updated reflections
Updated textures (on most things)
All DLC included

Cons:
Broken APEX PhysX integration (cloth physics and smoke physics not functional)
Flickering on particles and lights
Mafia 3 shaders and lighting clash with the feeling and setting of the original title
Some cutscene NPC's use old textures, creating jarring visuals

Ultimately, Mafia 2 is an incredible game, from the narrative to the gameplay it doesn't miss a beat. It's great that the game has been modernized to be introduced to a new generation of gamers, but this remaster isn't satisfactory. Either through rushing or negligence, some of the original graphical aspects have been completely removed or worsened (APEX and shading.)
I sincerely hope they patch out some of the issues, but this release could be considered nothing more than a beta release in my opinion. Not worth the money until these glaring issues are fixed, in my opinion this is currently inferior to the original release, even by modern standards.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Doesn't work with windows 7 without editing files and XMLs.

So they took a 10 year old game made for windows 7 and made it NOT work with windows 7.

Even with xinput1_4 mod the game will start and run but controller will not work. KBAM still works fine.

NVIDIA PHYSX NO LONGER UTILIZED! So everything that made the original version so amazing from tire deformation to clothing physics to snow to certain debris is now gone and replaced with static and hard models that creates clipping and strange rigid clothing. Even doing the XML edit you can get "some" PhysX features enabled but at about half of what the "classic" version has.

So they took a 10 year old game, added slightly better textures, then took away a bunch of features that made the original game so good, then made it not work on the operating system it was made for.

Talk about a bungled "re"launch.

Unless you really care more about 4k textures, then I'd say the "classic" version still looks better if you are still running 1080p or 1440p, as there really isn't that big of a difference to justify the loss of PhysX goodies and the increase of more than 35gb vs the classic only needing about 8 gb.

If you really want to see what this game could have looked like if they didn't bungle the "definitive edition" check out 2 mods on nexusmods for "classic" Mafia 2 called: 

-"Mafia II Remastered" and "Old Time Reality Mod" These do a much better job at tightening up graphics with lighting, shaders, and 4k textures as well as a few more addons like 20 more cars, 70 more songs, better damage models and more.

Again, modders doing a better job for free than what a multi-million dollar company does.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
Loved the original game, so naturally couldn't wait to play this.

Some questions I've seen from other reviews:

1. Is it worth £24.99? No. (Hopefully you got the free upgrade like myself)

2. Is physx in the game? Yes. (People have reviewed this game thinking it's not because it's not in the settings menu, however it's a hidden setting which is only turned on if you select medium or high preset for all graphic options, a tip for those having frame drops issues is to set the games graphics settings to the low preset, restart the game and it will turn off physx, then turn your game back to what ever graphic settings you wish but do it manually do not use the slider preset at the top as that will turn physx back on, you only have to do this once, if you want physx back on use medium or high preset restart game and do your graphic settings manually again and your done, you can also enable or disable this in the game files instead)

3. Slow motion bug from the original game fixed? Yes.

4. Texture bugs? Haven't come across any yet.

5. Audio bugs? Haven't come across any yet.

6. Custom controller settings? No. (Only 2 presets to pick from like the original game)

Free overall rating? 9/10.

Purchased overall rating? 6/10. (Overpriced, £10-£15 would be good in my opinion)

review:
Over 10 years ago I first played Mafia, and pre-ordered Mafia II for the Xbox 360. To see them being remastered is awesome since these games hold a special place in my heart, especially since they clearly haven't been forgotten either...

...However, I can respect those who think the definitive edition is a downgrade due to bugs, graphical errors, and of course the lack/removal of Apex PhysX. Though personally, I'm just glad I got this for free, and those things generally seem to bother me, I can understand a lot of the frustration people are feeling. I also think the price tag is a bit too pricey considering its not an entire remake of the first Mafia game, and there was no implementation of cut content or even new content as a matter of fact.

With all this being mentioned, I still find myself enjoying Mafia II as if I bought it 10 years ago all the same. Would I recommend this at full price? Probably not. But if you received it for free since you have the classic Mafia II, might as well play it.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
To Enable PhysX view this review - https://steamcommunity.com/id/ketaro/recommended/1030830/

Mafia II: Definitive Edition is literally just that, it's Mafia 2 but better.

Pros
- Improved Textures
- Improved Lighting
- Improved Models
- Better Frame rate and Optimisation
- Same amazing story and characters

Cons
- Fov can be awful at times with no way in game to change, external methods are seemingly possible but don't seem to work for me (This is not exclusive to this version, Mafia 2 Classic also requires external methods) not unplayable by any means but would be nice to have the option in game.

Possible Issues
- My PhysX was apparently already enabled but you will need to double check the top of the review and just make sure it's set to high if you want it in game.
- People are reporting sound issues with headphones and only coming out the left ear however this doesn't happen on my end so just something to watch out for.

It's not quite the re-make that Mafia 1 is getting but in all fairness it doesn't really need it. It's a fantastic game that's even more worth playing now.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
I think the biggest issue with this remaster is that it doesn't [i]look[/i] like a remaster. Taking a look at comparison videos, a lot of the textures did get upgraded... but to less blurrier textures. At least with remasters like Burnout Paradise, every textures looks crisp and clean. However, it just seems that you are just playing the original game since many textures are still low quality and blurry. Also, none of the models were updated to higher quality ones. Here is a video to show what I mean: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nnt-5SLMP0U
Then comes the issue with Apex, and PhysX. From what I understand, NVIDIA PhysX is still there, especially since the logo is shown when you start the game, but the option to enable/disable isn't in the menus anymore. However, the Apex coat physics seem to be gone or at least disabled. Once we find out more, then I'll update this.

I'm still happy I got it for free for owning Mafia II, but for the people who were looking for a true remaster, this isn't it.

[/strike]

I have to say, though, that they did this in a very not-a**hole-ish way - you get the original plus the definitive edition for the same old price (although they'll probably put it on sale less now) and I got all of the DLCs for the old version.

I just hope that Mafia I will be well made, so Hangar 13 can at least partly make up for the f**kup of this amazing series by the third installment.

EDIT: There is Czech dubbing but you have to pick it in the game launcher, not in steam like I'm used to.

title: Mafia II Definitive Edition
review:
From the just 30 or so minutes of playing, I can say that it seems somewhat better than the original,

However currently, my anti-virus disables the launcher stating it to be a virus, and so this has forced me to turn off my anti-virus just to be able to play the game. I thought there'd be a silver lining when I saw you could disable the launcher, but it doesn't truly disable it, it just starts, then immediately skips. This is a pain, because it means that if I wan't to play the game, I need to keep my anti-virus turned off (which I really don't like to do).

Another thing I noticed which really annoyed me, was the fact that when I exited the game, the game continues to run the executable in the background, and when I go to turn off the exe in the task manager, it tells me I can't. The only way for me to fully close the game is to restart my computer entirely.

I was really looking forward to this remaster too, but until these problems are dealt with, I won't be playing the game, and I can't recommend buying it if you didn't get it for free. Honestly, I'd just play the classic version, it may not be graphically better, but it is the same game, and at least you can play that without having to disable your entire anti-virus software.

If these problems get fixed, then I'll be able to continue with the game, and my review will be changed.

My opinion? No. If you haven't played it yet, buy the original. It's cheaper, it's the same game and it honestly feels a little better. If 4k matters to you and space doesn't, and you really have money to burn.. I guess go for it? You really aren't gaining much. As it stands, I can't recommend paying money for this remaster. 

Almost as big a disappointment as Mafia 3.

The game's story is still as perfect as it was in 2010, only now with higher graphical fidelity; game looks more like a 2014 game than a 2010 game, if you get what I'm saying. Other than that one problem, the definitive edition is a worthy purchase and if you already own Mafia II, there's no reason to not play through the story one more time.

The graphics look near identical compared to the OG. The lighting has the largest improvement and the textures are relatively improved but it's not that revolutionary.
